title: Japanese and American Impressions of Isolation
description: The two short halves - 20 minutes and 25 minutes - of the dance program Thursday night at the Kitchen, repeated last night, made for a curiously harmonious pairing. Despite the cultural gulf between the Butoh-inspired Japanese duo before the intermission and the workaday natural movement of the American septet afterwards, they conveyed a similar mood of Minimalist isolation and anomie.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Procter & Gamble's Acquisition of Gillette Cleared The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that federal regulators cleared its proposed $57 billion acquisition of the razor maker Gillette provided that it sell the Right Guard brand of deodorant and the Rembrandt line of toothpaste and oral care products. The company, which is based in Cincinnati, said it expected to complete the acquisition today and would start shedding the Gillette brands in the October-December quarter. (AP)

title: Arts, Briefly; Minimalist Theme Music
description: The Minimalist composer Philip Glass, below, has written his first theme for a television series. Mr. Glass, creator of operas like "Einstein on the Beach" and film scores including "The Hours," composed the title music for ABC's new drama "Night Stalker." It will make its debut with the second episode, Thursday night. "I just thought it was very interesting," Mr. Glass said of accepting the commission. "How do you write a 30-second piece? Everything is extremely compressed." In fact, the opening title sequence lasts just 20 seconds. (A 30-second version accompanies the end credits.) Composed for two pianos, strings and harp, the theme includes the composer's signature arpeggios. JOHN BURLINGAME

title: High and Dry on the Farm

title: Life for Feeding Man to Lions
description: To the whistles and ululations of a packed courtroom, a white farmer who ordered a black former worker beaten and thrown to lions 20 months ago was sentenced to life imprisonment, and his accomplice was sentenced to 15 years. The farmer, Mark Scott-Crossley, above, became a symbol of what some say is enduring racism in South Africa after his crime was revealed in early 2004. His lawyers had said his crime was rooted in a life filled with psychological trauma, but the judge said a crime so monstrous demanded the harshest sentence. The dead farm worker, Nelson Chisale, was beaten with sticks and tied for seven hours to a tree before being loaded into a pickup and driven to a reserve of rare white lions, where he was tossed over the fence. The police were able to retrieve only scraps of clothing and bone fragments from the pen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRZUSTOWICZ, STANLEY, D.D.S.
description: BRZUSTOWICZ -- Stanley, D.D.S. Dean Ira B. Lamster, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, notes with deep sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Stanley Brzustowicz, Professor Emeritus of Clinical Dentistry, on September 28, 2005. He graduated from Saint John's University in 1940 and received his D.D.S. from Columbia University in 1943. A member of the Columbia faculty for more than 60 years, Dr. Brzustowicz was a devoted alumnus and educator. He was the course director for preclinical operative dentistry at the School and leaves a legacy of dedicated service to countless students and to the profession. As a clinician, he provided exemplary care to his many patients. He was a member of the Division of Operative Dentistry since his graduation in 1943. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Wanda and the entire family.

title: Arts, Briefly; Paintings Seized
description: Federal marshals seized dozens of paintings on Thursday from a gallery in Wisconsin in a copyright dispute that has underscored worries among American artists about an influx of cheap art from China, lawyers for both sides said yesterday. The marshals seized the paintings in a copyright infringement lawsuit filed by Thomas Arvid, an American painter of wine and wine bottles, against the Gold Coast gallery in Lake Geneva, Wis. David C. Williams, a lawyer for the gallery, said the paintings were made in China but did not violate copyrights. Handmade paintings are not necessarily covered by copyright law, because they are not exact duplicates of original works, he said. Peter J. Strand, a lawyer who is representing Mr. Arvid, said that the seized paintings did not carry copies of Mr. Arvid's signatures but in some cases matched his wine bottle paintings "down to the lettering on the corks." Theodore H. Feder, the president of the Artists Rights Society, an advocacy group in New York, said handmade paintings could violate copyrights even if there were "slight deviations" from the original work. KEITH BRADSHER

title: Four Soldiers Killed in Border Clashes in Pakistan
description: At least four soldiers were killed, including a major, and scores were wounded as the military pressed ahead with an operation in the mountainous North Waziristan tribal area straddling the Afghan border, military officials said. Pakistani troops, accompanied by gunship helicopters, moved into an area southwest of Miran Shah, the main town in North Waziristan, and faced stiff resistance. "The militants are a mix of local and foreign elements," said Maj. Gen Shaukat Sultan, spokesman for the military. He said the military did not know many militants might have been killed. The semi-autonomous tribal areas bordering Afghanistan have long been though to be safe havens for Taliban and Qaeda sympathizers.

title: Canadian Economy Grew 0.2 Percent in July
description: Canada's economy grew by 0.2 percent in July, down from 0.3 percent a month earlier, Statistics Canada reported yesterday. The government agency said that the mining, oil and gas sectors showed 3.6 percent growth. Oil and gas exploration activity alone rose 20 percent. However, those gains, and growth in other sectors, were offset by a 0.3 percent decline in the manufacturing sector and a 2.5 percent drop in utility output. Wholesale trade also fell by 1.4 percent caused partly by lagging sales of computers and electronics as well as lumber. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Jail, Not Extradition, for Colombian Warlord
description: Diego Fernando Murillo, a paramilitary commander being held in comfort on a sprawling ranch, has been transferred to Cmbita, one of Colombia's toughest prisons, President lvaro Uribe announced. The abrupt transfer came a day after Mr. Uribe said Mr. Murillo, known as Don Berna, could avoid extradition to New York on drug trafficking charges if he adhered to a pact governing the disarmament of thousands of paramilitary fighters. The Bush administration has strongly backed Mr. Uribe's dealing with the paramilitaries, but federal prosecutors in New York have been pushing for Mr. Murillo to be extradited to face cocaine-trafficking charges.

title: NBC Moves Martha Stewart to Later Time Slot After a Sluggish Start to Her New Reality Show

After two surprisingly low-rated episodes, NBC decided yesterday to remove "The Apprentice Martha Stewart" from its 8 p.m. spot, placing it at 9 p.m., where it will go head-to-head against one of prime time's strongest shows, "Lost" on ABC. In its place NBC is moving up its 9 p.m. show, "E-Ring," a drama set in the Pentagon, which has also been disappointing in its first two outings. NBC executives said they hoped that "E-Ring" might add viewers by being the only drama at 8 p.m. Wednesday and that "Martha" might gain a few reality TV fans because at 9 it would not face another in that genre, as it has at 8 against "America's Next Top Model" on UPN. She attended Rutgers, The State University and William Paterson University of New Jersey, before leaving for a variety of writing positions at New Jersey radio stations. description: ACCORDING to the tired journalistic trope, the "intelligent design" trial in Harrisburg, Pa., is "Scopes II," or the latest cultural clash between science and religion. But that view obscures the issues at stake -- issues I am happy to see the Pennsylvania trial raising, even though I am a religious believer who recognizes evolution and does not think intelligent design theory belongs in any school's science curriculum.

title: A Choreographer and a Composer, Both Confounding Expectations
description: The Ligeti Festival opened at the Miller Theater on Wednesday night, quite properly, with a dance program called "Watching Ligeti Move." That Hungarian composer does not come readily to mind for dance, but Christopher Wheeldon has seen (or heard) dance in Ligeti's music. And the evening's three ballets suggested why a choreographer, particularly one of Mr. Wheeldon's far-reaching sensibilities, might turn to Ligeti's works.

title: Contract Killers
description: Washington - This is a political witch hunt," Representative Tom DeLay told reporters on Wednesday, shortly after a Texas grand jury indicted him on conspiracy charges, forcing him to step down as House majority leader. Later he called Ronnie Earle, the district attorney who has investigated Mr. DeLay's Texans for a Republican Majority political action committee for two years, a "partisan fanatic." He said the inquiry into his political fundraising was "a sham," and that "Mr. Earle knows it." And he notified his enemies that the indictment would not slow down the Republican agenda, such as it is.

title: Leo Sternbach, 97, Valium Creator, Dies
description: Leo H. Sternbach, a research chemist who was foremost among the team of scientists who developed Valium, the tranquilizer that has been prescribed to millions of the sleepless and anxiety-ridden since the 1960's, died on Wednesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 97.

title: Moments of Clarity, Lost and Found
description: MILAN, Sept. 29 - If there was a lesson to be learned from the Italian spring collections, which ended tonight, it was stay true to your roots even after they have gone gray. Karl Lagerfeld set Fendi on a fresh course with some of the prettiest clothes of the season -- and that's clothes, not furs or bags. At the opposite extreme, Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce, celebrating their 20th year in fashion, unwittingly exposed the price of success.

title: Chlorine Leak Closes Roads in New Jersey

description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30 - The federal aviation administrator announced on Friday that a $15billion expansion of O'Hare International Airport was "now cleared for takeoff." But within hours of a ceremonial groundbreaking here, a federal court granted critics of the expansion a stay temporarily halting the federal approval.

But after the extraordinary destructiveness of Hurricane Katrina less than a month earlier, it seemed almost like a blessing that it wasn't worse.

title: 3 More Sought in C.I.A. Case in Italy
description: The police have ordered the arrests of three more people accused of being Central Intelligence Agency operatives -- including a former official in the American Embassy in Rome -- bringing to 22 the number of people linked to the C.I.A and wanted in Italy for the kidnapping of a terror suspect from Milan in 2003. The suspect, Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, a radical cleric, was flown to his native Egypt, where he was imprisoned and, his family says, tortured. All 22 wanted in the case are believed to have left Italy.

description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 - Although the Cleveland Indians lost, 3-2, to the Chicago White Sox in 13 innings Friday night -- their fourth defeat in five games -- they remained quite alive in the competition to reach the playoffs.

Gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent last quarter A the15th quarterly increase in a row A but median household income remains belowwhat it was in 1999. Corporate profits grew by 6.9 percent in the second quarter,but bankruptcy filings were also 12 percent higher than in the same period lastyear, when household debt reached a record high. And so on.

title: Arts, Briefly; Clark Kent Muscles In
description: As the torrent of network premieres continued, CBS's "Without a Trace" (21.13 million), NBC's "Will & Grace" (9.65 million), ABC's "Alias" (8.09 million) and "Night Stalker" (7.13 million), and WB's "Smallville" (5.74 million) and "Everwood" (3.57 million) made their fall debuts on Thursday night. CBS was No. 1 by a wide margin in Nielsen's estimates, as it nearly always is on Thursdays, but it was "Smallville" that provided the night's surprise upsets. The Season 5 opener was the top-ranked show in the 8 p.m. hour among men 18 to 34, its target audience, beating even CBS's "Survivor" (17.13 million total viewers) in that group. "Smallville" also surpassed "Alias" among 18-to-49-year-olds. Also at 8 p.m. was the second episode of UPN's "Everybody Hates Chris," which was down from its debut last week (from 7.78 million to 5.65 million) but still a ratings improvement over wrestling, which formerly occupied the time period. CBS's "CSI" was the night's most-watched show (27.20). KATE AURTHUR

title: Arts, Briefly; Russian 'Ring' Is New York-Bound
description: Valery Gergiev, right, and his Kirov Opera of St. Petersburg are bringing their acclaimed "Ring des Nibelungen" production to the Metropolitan Opera house. They will present the cycle twice there in July 2007 in the latest export of the all-Russian Ring, which has played in Baden-Baden, Seoul and Moscow, and will appear at the Orange County Performing Arts Center next October. The New York performances are a joint venture of the Lincoln Center Festival and the Metropolitan Opera. The festival director, Nigel Redden, said the cost was in the multimillions, but declined, along with the Met, to be more specific or to discuss how the two presenters would share the burden. In a telephone interview, Mr. Gergiev said that Wagner has had a resurgence in Russia in recent years, after decades of being ignored because of historical enmity with Germany. The performances of the Kirov "Ring" at the Maryinsky Theater in 2003 were among the first in Russia since the revolution, Mr. Gergiev said. "It's certainly better to do it late rather than never," he said. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPENCER, THOMAS F.
description: SPENCER--Thomas F. 61. Died August 28 of cancer. Of New York and Middlebury, CT. After graduating from Taft and Union College, Tom was a U.S. Navy officer in Vietnam, decorated with the Purple Heart for injuries suffered in the river war in the Mekong Delta. Upon his return to the States in 1971 Tom earned his MBA from Wharton and held management positions with A.T. Kearney, Phelps Dodge and Crane Corp. An independent investor for the past 15 years, Tom also advised the Polish government on privatization, and was a consultant on industrial restructuring projects in Russia and China, and supervised elections for the OSCE in Bosnia, Kosovo, Belarus and Armenia. He was also active in numerous organizations, including The Union Club, Explorers Club, St. George's Society, Holland Lodge No. 8, Naval Order of the US, St. Nicholas Society, Soc. of the Cincinnati, Nat'l Arts Club and The Pilgrims. Tom's family and wide range of friends and acquaintances will miss the loyalty, courage, generosity, fellowship, unique sense of humor and crazy hats of this true and memorable gentleman. His many friends among the members and staff of the Union Club

title: The Backup Candidate
description: One day this past July, Rick Lazio stepped out of the sticky, stifling heat of the Washington summer and into the cool, cerebral embrace of the Council on Foreign Relations, which keeps an office on Massachusetts Avenue just east of Dupont Circle. Lazio, the former congressman and onetime United States Senate candidate, can usually be found these days delivering speeches before business executives and dining with high government officials on behalf of J.P. Morgan Chase, the financial services firm where he is an executive vice president. But on this particular day he came to spend three hours in a smallish first-floor conference room meeting with members of the council's Africa Task Force, essentially a midlevel bull session about United States policy toward foreign countries that, if you named them, most Americans would assume were planets in some Spielbergian science-fiction epic.

title: The Buckley Effect
description: Forty years after it was decided, the mayoral race of 1965 remains one of the most memorable elections in New York history. It was also one of the strangest, thanks in large part to the candidacy of William F. Buckley Jr. It was odd enough that Buckley, author, magazine editor, columnist, debater and gadfly - with no experience in practical politics - should have sought this most thankless of jobs. Odder still that his campaign style invited comparisons with Oscar Wilde, Evelyn Waugh, Noel Coward and Mort Sahl. But oddest of all was that he was taken seriously - seriously enough to confound opponents, observers and analysts and throw the election up for grabs. Although it wasn't clear at the time, Buckley's bid for office was an important chapter in one of the crucial events in modern political history, the transformation of the consensus politics of the peak cold-war years of the 1950's and early 60's, its agenda set by liberals, into the more polarized politics of our era, ruled by conservatives.

description: MACK--John Duncan. Of Concord, MA. and Chatham, MA. died suddenly on September 27 while in England. He was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1924. As a marketing executive, he worked at Welch's, Procter & Gamble, Clairol and Gillette. From 1976-1992, he was President of Carter Products in New York City. John also served as President of Wave Hill; on the Township Committee of East Amwell, NJ and as Deputy Mayor; and as a Trustee of St. John's College. In Concord, he served as a Trustee of The Thoreau Society and Thoreau Farm Trust; and on the Historic District Commission. John is survived by his wife Lorna Carey Mack; his sisters, Anne Dean and Mary Hurst; his daughters, Pamela Mack, Sheila Mack, Carey Weber and Lorna Sheridan; and 7 grandchildren. Memorial Contributions may be made to Thoreau Farm Trust, Box 454, Concord, MA. 01742.

title: Inside the List
description: BEAUTY MARK: Zadie Smith's third novel, "On Beauty," enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 7. It's her second book to make the list in hardcover -- "White Teeth," her first novel, spent three weeks on this chart in the summer of 2000, rising only as high as No. 14. In interviews, Smith has been blazingly articulate about her desire, as her deserved fame grows, to maintain some semblance of privacy. "I refuse to do any television and I won't do anything which makes my life un-normal," she recently told The Guardian of London. "But it's amazing! 'Do you want to go on a dating program, do you want to stand on your head in the park?' It's constant. But I won't go on the front cover of a magazine. I won't do any of it. . . . The other day I was having lunch here, and this man just stared and stared and stared and stared and stared, and finally I just said to him: 'Just stop now. I'm eating.' I won't be made a freak!" Comments like that have not always endeared her to the British press, however, which has been critical of Smith since she dissed England in an interview with New York magazine. "It's funny that Zadie loathes being recognized so much," Janet Street-Porter intoned in The Independent of London, "because in the new issue of British Vogue . . . she's gritted her teeth and consented to be photographed for a fashion spread in a clinging halter-necked satin evening gown with flowers in her hair." Yet Street-Porter closed her article by writing about Smith: "Come back home from New York, all is forgiven."

title: Heinlein's Female Troubles
description: Preparations are underway for a huge celebration to commemorate the centennial of Robert A. Heinlein, the legendary science-fiction author who in 1975 was named the first ever Grand Master by the Science Fiction Writers of America. The celebration, set for July 7, 2007, Heinlein's birthday, will consist of three separate sections: one for fans, one for academics and a third for a group not usually associated with fiction, genre or otherwise -- aerospace professionals. But Heinlein holds a unique place in this world; many scientists and engineers who built the first United States spacecraft (as well as today's space-tourism entrepreneurs) cite his novels as their inspiration. Larry Niven, a sci-fi writer, spoofs this in "The Return of William Proxmire," a time-travel yarn written in 1988. In Niven's tale, Senator Proxmire, a notorious critic of the American space program, journeys back to the 1930's, carrying present-day antibiotics. Proxmire aims to cure Heinlein of the tuberculosis that ended his Navy career and inaugurated his literary one. If Heinlein never writes a story, Proxmire reasons, the money-wasting space program can be scrubbed before it launches.

Dr. Tassone, the former Roslyn school superintendent, pleaded guilty to stealing $2 million of the $11 million that officials estimate was looted from the school district, and agreed to cooperate with the district attorney, Denis Dillon, who has several defendants to go before he is done with this scandal. In return, Dr. Tassone, who has promised to pay back his share of what has been called the biggest theft from a school system in American history, will probably face only 4 to 12 years in prison, not a maximum of 25. Hapless pot smokers have done more hard time than that.

Mr. Collins graduated from The Kent School in 1948 and Princeton University in 1952, where he also earned a Masters in Architecture. He commenced a long and distinguished career in real estate development, including founding Collins Development in 1969 and developing many waterfront and historic preservation projects in the Northeast. Mr. Collins is survived by his wife Judith Ann Paixao Collins and his stepson Benjamin Coulter, both of Wilton. He is also survived by his first wife Joan Collins of Darien and their three children Arthur Collins of Darien, Dwight Collins of Darien and Merrill Collins of Norwalk. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIBNER, DAVID
description: DIBNER--David. On Wednesday, September 28, 2005, David Dibner, accomplished businessman, philanthropist and civic leader, died unexpectedly at his home in Wilton, CT. Mr. Dibner, who was Chairman of the Dibner Fund, a family foundation, and former Chairman of the Burndy Corporation, was 78 years old. Mr. Dibner had a long and distinguished career. After serving in the navy in WWII, he trained as an engineer at Columbia University and continued with post-graduate studies at the London School of Economics. In 1968 he attended the Advanced Management Program at Harvard University. In his more than 30-year career at the Burndy Corporation, a leading multinational manufacturer of electrical and electronic connectors and tools, he rose from engineer to chairman of the board. Mr. Dibner was also an exceptional and committed civic leader. In Wilton, the community where he and his wife, Frances Kessler Dibner, resided for 53 years, he spearheaded and chaired the building of the Wilton High School, as well being chair and an active board member of the Norwalk Hospital. His involvement extended to business, academic and philanthropic sectors: he was a founding member of the American Business Conference and an active trustee of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn. He also served on the boards of Columbia University School of Engineering, the American Technion Society and was a member of the Committee for the Humanities at MIT. In addition, he was a fellow of the Aspen Institute and a member of the Council on Foundations. In 1989, following the death of his father, Bern Dibner, Mr. Dibner assumed responsibility for the Dibner Fund, a family philanthropy, and the Burndy Library, one of the world's outstanding collections of rare books, manuscripts, incunabula and objects in the field of the history of science and technology. Together with his wife Frances and with support of the Dibner Fund, Mr. Dibner established the Dibner Institute for the History of Science and Technology, a center for advanced study located along with the Burndy Library on the campus of MIT. In addition to the Fund's deep commitment to scholarship in the field of history of science and technology, Mr. Dibner oversaw the Fund's national and international grantmaking in science education, humanitarian aid, the environment, peaceful coexistence, Jewish heritage and culture, and local community organizations. Mr. Dibner was an avid gardener and landscaper. His hobbies included woodworking, sculpting, sailing, hiking, and travel. He deeply loved the American west for its history, art, indigenous culture and landscape. Above all else he was a loving and devoted husband to his wife of 55 years. He was a proud and loving father to his sons and daughters-in law: Brent and Relly (Wolfson) Dibner, Daniel and Victoria (Clark) Dibner, and Mark and Rachel(Zax) Dibner. He was an adored and loved by his grandchildren, Gil, Tal, Carmel, Aurora, Avalon, Bern, Sage and Skye. A memorial service will be held in the near future. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Mr. Dibner's memory to the Norwalk Hospital Foundation, the Wilton Volunteer Ambulance Corps or a charity of personal choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, GONNIE MCCLUNG
description: SIEGEL--Gonnie McClung died September 29th, age 77, in Gainesville, Florida, from complications of Alzheimer's disease. She had previously lived in the Florida Keys and in Bedford, N.Y. She was born in the Appalachian mountain hamlet of Mt. Lookout, West Virginia. Her ancestors were among the earliest European settlers of western Virginia and also included Native Americans of the Mingo tribe. She attended Davis and Elkins College and received a degree in Journalism from West Virginia University. She was the author of four books: "Sales: the Fast track for Women"; "The Women's Workbook"; "How to Beat the High Cost of Learning", a definitive guide to the Student Loan Program, and "How to Advertise and Promote Your Small Business". She also ran Gonnie Siegel Associates, a Westchester public relations agency. A lifelong feminist, she was a founding member of the Westchester N.Y. chapter of the National Organization for Women. She is survived by her husband, Robert J. Siegel, a retired IBM communications executive, and her brother, Lake M. McClung, both of Gainesville. Also two sons, William Laird Siegel of Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, and Richard Joseph Siegel of Katonah, N.Y., and two grandsons, Nicholas and Rory Siegel of Katonah, along with a number of nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held in early December at Bahia Honda in the Florida Keys.

title: CORRECTION
description: In describing the results of the ballot study by the group led by The Miami Herald in his column of Aug. 26, Paul Krugman relied on the Herald report, which listed only three hypothetical statewide recounts, two of which went to Al Gore. There was, however, a fourth recount, which would have gone to George W. Bush. In this case, the two stricter-standard recounts went to Mr. Bush. A later study, by a group that included The New York Times, used two methods to count ballots: relying on the judgment of a majority of those examining each ballot, or requiring unanimity. Mr. Gore lost one hypothetical recount on the unanimity basis.

title: 'Everyone Worth Knowing'
description: Though I'd caught only the briefest glimpse from the corner of my eye, I knew immediately that the brown creature darting across my warped hardwood floors was a water bug - the largest, meatiest insect I'd ever seen. The superbug had narrowly avoided skimming across my bare feet before it disappeared under the bookcase. Trembling, I forced myself to practice the chakra breathing I'd learned during an involuntary week at an ashram with my parents. My heart rate slowed slightly after a few concentrated breaths of re on the inhale and lax on the exhale, and within a few minutes I was functional enough to take some necessary precautions. First I rescued Millington (who was also cowering in terror) from her hiding place under the couch. Then, in quick succession, I zipped on a pair of knee-high leather boots to cover my exposed legs, opened the door to the hallway to encourage the bug's departure, and began spraying the extra-strong black-market vermin poison on every available surface in my minuscule one-bedroom. I gripped the trigger as though it were an assault weapon and was still spraying when the phone rang nearly ten minutes later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOTLEY, CONSTANCE BAKER
description: MOTLEY--Constance Baker. Dean David Schizer and the students, faculty and staff of Columbia Law School mourn the death of Constance Baker Motley, graduate of the Columbia Law School Class of 1946. While studying law at Columbia, she met Thurgood Marshall and began her illustrious career in the civil rights movement. Judge Motley won nine of the 10 cases she argued before the U.S. Supreme Court, as well as the landmark desegregation case that gained James Meredith admission to the University of Mississippi (the danger of such work was made clear when her colleague in the case, Medgar Evers, was murdered). Her intellect and legal acumen were fundamental to many civil rights victories won by more visible leaders like Thurgood Marshall and Martin Luther King, Jr., whom she once counseled in a four-by-six jail cell in rural Georgia. In the early 1960s, she served as a New York state senator and as Manhattan borough president, the first African-American woman to hold either office. She subsequently became the first black woman appointed to a federal judgeship, and served with distinction on the bench of the Southern District of New York. In this time of sadness, we are reminded of the announcement accompanying her Presidential Citizens Medal in 2000: "As a dedicated public servant and distinguished judge, she has broken down political, social and professional barriers, and her pursuit of equal justice under law widened the circle of opportunity in America."

Paid Notice: Deaths   EASTMAN, LAURA DELANO ADAMS
description: EASTMAN -- Laura Delano Adams. 79, on September 23, 2005. Born on Campobello Island, New Brunswick, she was the daughter of Frederick Baldwin Adams and Ellen Walters Delano and grew up in the family home at 8 East 69th Street in Manhattan. She married Jack Eastman, Director of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, from whom she was amicably divorced and who predeceased her. Her late brother, Frederick B. Adams, Jr., was the former Director of the Morgan Library and a consummate bibliophile. She is survived by her dear companion Mary ("Bunny") Diehl, her nieces, Gillian Adams, Anne Adams Chambers, Judith Adams and Lauren Fortmiller, and, of course, her horse "Walker". Laura graduated from the Chapin School and Barnard College, and initially followed in her brother's footsteps becoming a knowledgeable and accomplished curator of private libraries and collections. She was a superb horsewoman specializing in showing fivegaited saddle horses, and was a supporter of many US Olympic Equestrian teams. While visiting her mother's cousins, Franklin and Eleanor, in the White House on December 7, 1941, she spent the afternoon teaching the President's dog, Fala, to roll over. She went on to raise and train dogs to assist deaf persons, helping to found the agency which coordinates such efforts, Assistance Dogs International. Her life-long devotion to the Metropolitan Opera led naturally to her involvement in the theater, and for many years she organized and directed the summer theater program at the Community House in Fire Island Pines, and was a supporter of the John Drew Playhouse in East Hampton. She took delight in telling how her friend Jerry Herman wrote "Hello Dolly" on the back deck of her bay cottage in the Pines, where she also served for many years on the board of FIPPOA. With her husband Jack and friend Henry Grady, she developed "Sandy Ground" in Jost Van Dyke, B.V.I., where she could pursue her interest in snorkeling. After surviving a serious encounter with cancer of the oropharynx, Laura dedicated herself as a patient-to-patient peer counselor for in-coming cancer patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, volunteering as many as five or six days a week for nearly twenty years. On Sundays, she could be found ushering at St. James's Church, Manhattan, or in attendance at St. Luke's in East Hampton or St. Ann's in Bridgehampton. She attended the Institute of Theology at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, was a Governor of The Laymen's Club of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, and was the former librarian of The Church Club of New York. She was a supporter of the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore, founded by her granduncle, Henry Walters. Her greatest charitable effort was with St. John Eye Hospital in East Jerusalem, for which, under a commission from Queen Elizabeth II, she was made a Dame of the Venerable Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem last September at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. Everyone who loved Laura is invited to a memorial service on October 20 at 11 A.M. at St. James's Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street. Instead of flowers, gifts in Laura's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center. A committal service at a date to be announced will follow at St. Luke's in East Hampton. In the Spring, a portion of Laura's ashes will be scattered at the Adams cabins on Campobello Island and into the Bay of Fundy.

But it has yet to fully emerge as the chic tropical destination --  la Miami Beach, about 30 miles to the south -- that the tourist trade envisions. To visit the seaside (and canal lined) South Florida city, which attracted more than nine million tourists last year, is to see it at a curious crossroads in time. There are still traces of the Fort Lauderdale of yesteryear, including a few mom-and-pop motels near the beach and a couple of boisterous bars that appeal to revelers in their 20's. title: 'New York Burning'
description: After ten feet of snow over Christmas, the skies cleared in January. In the brightening sun, poor widows and orphaned children hobbled through the snow to a house on Smith Street, across from the Black Horse Tavern, where a charity promised "To Feed the hungry & Cloath the naked," or at least those "in Real Need of Relief." But in February, the fierce weather returned. "We have now here a second Winter more Severe than it was some Weeks past," Zenger's Weekly Journal reported on February 2, the feast of Candlemas. "The Navigation of our River is again stopp'd by the Ice, and the poor in great want of Wood." At Peter DeLancey's farm outside the city, his "Spanish Negro" Antonio de St. Bendito, whose "Feet were frozen after the first great Snow," was still unable to walk. In the city, coals were passed out to the poor to help heat their humble homes. At John Hughson's tavern, his Irish servant girl, Mary Burton, dressed herself "in Man's Cloaths, put on Boots, and went with him in his Sleigh in the deep Snows of the Commons, to help him fetch Firewood for his Family." At David Machado's house, in the East Ward, his black slave Diana, driven to desperation by the ferocity of the cold and by the hopelessness of bondage, "took her own young Child from her Breast, and laid it in the Cold, that it froze to Death."

title: The Buckley Effect
description: Forty years after it was decided, the mayoral race of 1965 remains one of the most memorable elections in New York history. It was also one of the strangest, thanks in large part to the candidacy of William F. Buckley Jr. It was odd enough that Buckley, author, magazine editor, columnist, debater and gadfly -- with no experience in practical politics -- should have sought this most thankless of jobs. Odder still that his campaign style invited comparisons with Oscar Wilde, Evelyn Waugh, Noel Coward and Mort Sahl. But oddest of all was that he was taken seriously -- seriously enough to confound opponents, observers and analysts and throw the election up for grabs. Although it wasn't clear at the time, Buckley's bid for office was an important chapter in one of the crucial events in modern political history, the transformation of the consensus politics of the peak cold-war years of the 1950's and early 60's, its agenda set by liberals, into the more polarized politics of our era, ruled by conservatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, BURRILL, KATHLEEN R. F.
description: GRIFFIN-BURRILL-Kathleen R. F. Professor Emeritus of Turkish Studies at Columbia University, passed away suddenly following cardiac arrest in Seattle, Washington (USA), on September 18th. She was 81. Born in Canterbury, England, on March 8th, 1924, she worked for the British Council for over eight years, including five years on their staff in Turkey. Following her marriage in 1955 to Claude W. Burrill, she came to New York, where she obtained her PhD from Columbia University, with a dissertation on "The Quatrains of Nesimi, Fourteenth-century Hurufi". From 1957 until her retirement in 1999, Professor Burrill published works on folk, Ottoman and modern Turkish literature, as well as teaching courses at Columbia University on modern and Ottoman Turkish language and literature, and Islamic civilization, and serving as Chair of the Department of Middle East Languages and Cultures from 1985 to 1990. She was active and held posts in numerous professional associations, including the American Turkish Society (Board of Directors, Honorary Vice President 1974-1989), the Middle East Studies Association (Founding Fellow in 1967, Director 1974 -1976), the American Association of Teachers of Turkic Languages (Founding co-member, President and most recently President Emeritus), the Turkish Studies Association (Founding member and Director 19741976), and the Institute of Turkish Studies (Founding Associate, Governing Board Member and Secretary-Treasurer). In order to be near family, she moved to Seattle in April 2001, from Princeton, NJ, where she had resided since her divorce in 1991. She is survived by her daughter, Jane Burrill Santiago, and son-in-law, Bart Santiago, who were with her at the time of her death, as well as by her elder daughter, Anne Burrill; son-in-law, Alberto Noriega Guerra; and her three grandchildren, Paloma, Roberto and Aygul, who live in Belgium but had all visited her during the summer. Over the years, she has touched many lives on different continents and will be dearly missed. Her ashes will be taken "home" to England for final burial, alongside her beloved parents.

title: So the Jains, They Have a Problem With Beef in the School Lunches. Who They Gonna Call?
description: It was the night of this year's New York primary, and when a billionaire like Mayor Michael Bloomberg holds a party to celebrate his candidacy, it's no small affair. The spacious ballroom of the Marriott in downtown Brooklyn was overflowing with free beer and pigs-in-blankets, and a band revved up the throngs of supporters. "We love Mike! We love Mike!" they chanted. Among the supporters was Alex Martins, a goateed Indian lawyer in a business suit and a Hawaiian shirt. He was flanked by three fellow Indians in shirt-sleeves who looked a little lost. Martins waved a big blue Bloomberg poster enthusiastically and joined in the chant; his entourage stood around silently.

title: Even MetroCards Are Manhattan Snobs
description: New turnstiles that have been installed in the PATH system have been hailed as a godsend for commuters, who can now use their New York City MetroCards in the system. But the cards, or the machines, or something, did not get the memo. There appears to be a glitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASSUMMA, CLARA M.
description: ASSUMMA--Clara M. A former resident of Eastchester, NY, died peacefully with her children by her side, on September 29, 2005. Born in Queens, NY, on July 9, 1926, to Joseph and Rosalia Cannata. Devoted wife of the late Daniel for 46 years (April 17, 1995). Beloved mother of Daniel of Somers, NY, Frank of Old Chatham, NY, Joanna of Pottersville, NJ, Peter of Chestnut Ridge, NY, and John of Waccabuc, NY. Caring sister of Antoinette Cannata, Bronx, NY, and predeceased brothers Placido and Salvatore. Cherished grandmother of 15, great-grandmother of one. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated, 10 AM, on Tuesday, Immaculate Heart of Mary, in Scarsdale, NY. Burial will follow, Mount Calvary Cemetery, White Plains, NY. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Donations may be made in Clara M. Assumma's memory to WGA Caddie Scholarship Fund, c/o Assumma-Shankey Funeral Home, 34 North Summit Street, Pearl River, NY 10965. Assumma-Shankey Funeral Home, Pearl River, NY: 845735-4849.

title: When Eating Doesn't Have to Be a Big Event
description: ON Sept. 18, I reviewed Michael Jordan's Steak House at Mohegan Sun, planning to compare it this week with a less expensive restaurant, Angus Steak House in Old Saybrook.

title: Low-Tech Security
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has roughly $600 million in state and federal funds to spend on making its system and its many customers safe from a terrorist attack. Some of this money has been committed to big-ticket items, including a three-year, $212 million contract to the Lockheed Martin Corporation to saturate the subways with 1,000 video cameras, 3,000 motion sensors and other fancy gizmos. The authority has also invited bids from big communications companies to install a wireless network covering 277 of its 468 subways stations to allow passengers to use cell phones.

title: On Television, Brands Go From Props to Stars
description: LATER this month on "The Office," Michael Scott, the painfully clueless regional manager of a paper supply company, will embrace casual Fridays in his own inimitable style. Eager to show off his newly trim physique, particularly his backside, the character -- played by Steve Carell -- will proudly model his new jeans to his alternately befuddled and appalled employees. And to anyone who will listen, he will proclaim something along the lines of "I love my new Levi's."

title: At Molloy, Education Is Not the Only Goal
description: HALF a century ago, many women's colleges were little more than finishing schools. But the Dominican Sisters of Amityville, who founded Molloy Catholic College for Women in 1955, had greater expectations for the 44 women who enrolled.

title: Alexandra Hughes and Neal Fiertag
description: Alexandra Hughes, a mezzo-soprano, and Neal Alan Fiertag, an art dealer, are to be married today at the Central Park Boathouse in New York. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, an Episcopal priest and the dean emeritus of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, will officiate.

title: Residential Up-and-Comer: Union City
description: UNION CITY - IT was probably inevitable: Hobokenization. Hoboken, a formerly rough-hewn riverside city that became "Manhattanized" over the last 15 years, replete with rehabbed condominiums and "new urban" style apartments, is now generating its own spillover effect -- perhaps most noticeably here, in a small blue-collar community that sits above Hoboken on the Palisades Cliffs.

title: The Soil Makes the Sauvignon
description: Chardonnay grapes rule Burgundy. But in St.-Bris, a tiny, virtually unknown appellation, Ghislaine and Jean-Hugues Goisot produce organic sauvignon blanc. Their 2004 is sensational. This appetite-whetting cool-climate wine gets its mineral character from the very chalk and limestone soils that make Chablis flinty. It has the herbal flavor of a delicate sauvignon from Sancerre, in the Loire. Pour it, lightly chilled, with trout, sole and grilled shrimp.

title: The Way We Eat: Preacher Comforts
description: Al Sharpton, the reverend, politician and social agitator, is the kind of New York City fixture who would not quite fit in anywhere else. He's a little like a disco ball -- great for the dance floor but awkward in the living room or the diner. On the streets, he is as familiar a sight as a yellow taxi or the naked cowboy in Times Square. And when it comes to dining, he gives off the air of someone who is as happy eating pasta at Rao's as he is chomping on a hot dog at Shea Stadium. So I recently asked Sharpton, who is 50 years old: if it was his last day in New York City, where would he go for breakfast, lunch and dinner? And then I dined with him, all day long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLEY, C. HARVEY

He worked with the Penn Mutual Insurance Company for 42 years. Harvey was an active leader in many organizations including the following: past President of the New England Society, Secretary of the St. George's Society, V.P. of the S.S.M.A.C., past Master of his Masonic Lodge and past Presiding Officer of The Knight York Cross of Honor. Service will be on October 4, at the Church of the Incarnation, 205 Madison Ave, NYC, at 1 PM. Donations may be made to Kane Lodge Foundation, 71 West 23rd Street, or Church of the Incarnation.

title: Movies on TV
description: FINDING NEVERLAND (2004) Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz Marc Forster's drama about the man who wrote "Peter Pan" and the boys who inspired him is just a well-dressed tear-jerker in the end, but the cast and Mr. Forster add an enormous amount of dignity and charm. Johnny Depp plays J. M. Barrie, a Victorian gentleman with a bad marriage who finds himself drawn to a lovely widow (Kate Winslet) and her four sons. As Peter, the boy who grows closest to Barrie, Freddie Highmore (above, with Mr. Depp) is exceptional, especially when his mother's health fails. This is not exactly the way it happened in real life (Ms. Winslet's character was still very much married, for one thing), but that doesn't detract from a story about the magic of childhood and one man's understanding of the desire never to grow up.

title: A Letter From the Editor: It All Goes on the Permanent Record
description: MOST readers probably presume that those of us who write and edit newspapers hate corrections. That's not entirely true. If an Op-Ed article or an editorial says James Madison died in 1835 and a reader points out that it was 1836, we will run a correction with a certain satisfaction -- the same feeling of painless virtue you get when you tell the grocery cashier that yes indeed, your 53 cents in change can be donated to the March Against Diabetes.

title: Abortion Might Outgrow Its Need for Roe v. Wade
description: WITH the confirmation last week of John G. Roberts Jr. as chief justice of the United States, eyes turned to President Bush's next judicial nominee, who, on a closely divided court, may determine the fate of Roe v. But such speculation overlooks a paradox in the abortion wars: while combatants focus on the law, technology is already changing the future of abortion, with or without the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRETT, WILLIAM RANDALL, SR.
description: BARRETT--William Randall, Sr., age 87, of Spring Lake, Michigan (formerly New Canaan, CT, and Birmingham, Mich.), died Sunday, September 25, 2005. He was born May 30, 1918, to Randall and Maud (Rowe) Barrett in Allegan, MI; and he married Marguerite M. "Marty" Pocock June 18, 1938, in Ferndale, MI. She preceded him in death December 26, 1996. He married Betty (VanAllen) Miller August 3, 1998. Mr. Barrett earned a Bachelor of Science degree in chemical engineering from Michigan State University; and was the recipient of the MSU Distinguished Alumni Award. Mr. Barrett was formerly the CEO for Rinshed-Mason Co. in Detroit; former chairman and CEO of Inmont Corp. of New York City; and a former executive vice president of United Technologies of Hartford, CT. Mr. Barrett moved to Spring Lake, MI, in 1981. He was formerly active at First Presbyterian Church of Grand Haven. His interests included golf, horticulture and photography. Survivors include his wife, Betty; two daughters, Joanne E. Barrett, Cambridge, MA; Wendy (David) J. Monson, Cadillac, MI; son, Robert L. Barrett, Traverse City, MI; daughterin-law, Linda Barrett, Rochester Hills, MI; Timothy (Nancy) Miller, Sacramento, CA; Jenet (Steve) Miller-Busch, Hawaii; Julia Miller, Grand Rapids, MI; 11 grandchildren and eight great - grandchildren. His son, William Randall Barrett, Jr., preceded him in death. A memorial service for William R. Barrett, Sr., will be held at 1:00 p.m., Monday, October 10, 2005, at the First Presbyterian Church, Grand Haven, MI, with Rev. Karin Fowler officiating. Private interment was in Spring Lake Cemetery. Memorials in lieu of flowers to CARE, PO Box 1871, Merrifield, VA 22116-9753, www.careusa.org, are appreciated. Share memories with the family at their online guest book at www.vbkfuneralhome.com. For information, call VanZantwick Bartels Kammeraad Funeral Homes, Inc., Spring Lake, Michigan.

Longer Lives Reveal the Ties That Bind Us
description: Let me tell you how we're going to die. Twenty percent of us, according to a Rand Corporation study, are going to get cancer or another rapidly debilitating condition and we'll be dead within a year of getting the disease. Another twenty percent of us are going to suffer from some cardiac or respiratory failure. We'll suffer years of worsening symptoms, a few life-threatening episodes, and then eventually die.

title: Correction
description: In describing the results of the ballot study by the group led by The Miami Herald in his column of Aug. 26, Paul Krugman relied on the Herald report, which listed only three hypothetical statewide recounts, two of which went to Al Gore. There was, however, a fourth recount, which would have gone to George W. Bush. In this case, the two stricter-standard recounts went to Mr. Bush. A later study, by a group that included The New York Times, used two methods to count ballots: relying on the judgment of a majority of those examining each ballot, or requiring unanimity. Mr. Gore lost one hypothetical recount on the unanimity basis.

title: Light Show
description: THE camera obscura -- a dark room that admits light through a small opening -- traces its lineage to Aristotle. But the one that took these images, on view through Nov. 12 at "Contemporary Obscurists," at the Alan Klotz Gallery, at 511 West 25th Street, has a lens that a NASA engineer designed. This camera obscura was built by Charles Schwartz, a photographer and dealer of photographs, in 1997 in his apartment 16 stories above Central Park. He has used the camera to capture dreamlike views of New York, projected onto a table top where his creative collaborator, Bill Westheimer (at right), puts them in finished form with a digital camera. NEW YORK IN FOCUS

title: Bye-Bye, Mr. American Pie: Paul Weitz Tries Sharp Satire
description: LOS ANGELES - LATE last year, the writer and director Paul Weitz set out to create a political satire about President George W. Bush and the war in Iraq. It seemed a risky proposition, both for the filmmaker -- known for his teen sex comedy "American Pie" and the wistful "About a Boy" -- and for the company that agreed to release it, NBC Universal: How the picture will play when it reaches theaters, next spring or later, may depend as much on world events and the gyrating fortunes of the American presidency as on Mr. Weitz's craft.

title: The Mysterious Mekong Starts to Reveal Itself
description: STEVE VAN BEEK, a 40-year veteran of expeditions in Asia, thought there were few places in the region he hadn't seen. But last year he found one. Running a kayaking trip down a tributary of the Mekong River in Laos, he says, he "walked through a cave straight out of Indiana Jones." Then, at the upper end of the cave, Mr. Van Beek and his clients exited into a valley and came upon an amazing sight -- a series of ruined temples and homes, remains of a sizable ancient town.

title: All Political Ideas Are Local
description: In January 1861, as Southern states were in the process of seceding from the union, Fernando Wood, the mayor of New York, made a modest proposal to his city council. New Yorkers -- whose city profited from the shipping of Southern cotton -- weren't crazy about the idea of a civil war. Wood's idea was that if the South severed its ties to the United States, New York should, too. Under his plan, the city would refashion itself into "a free city" called Tri-Insula -- comprising Manhattan, Staten Island and Long Island -- which would do business with both the North and South as they fought each other, thus sidestepping carnage and substituting business sense for patriotic fervor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, DAVID R.
description: KAHN--David R. In his 47th year. Loving husband of Susy; adoring father of Teddy and Daisy; beloved son of Joan and Mike Kahn, and son-in-law of Eva Rotmistrovsky and Hector Rotmistrovsky; and loving brother of Stefanie and Douglas Kahn; cherished uncle of Lauren, Michael and Daniel Kahn; adored nephew of Stanley Kahn and Gladys and Jerome Wiesenthal, his cousins Gary Kahn, Andrew and Billie Wiesenthal, Douglas Wiesenthal, Amy and Michael Liss and Richard Rotmistrovsky. We deeply mourn the loss of our much loved David, in whose company we reveled. David Kahn was the President and Chief Executive Officer of Croscill, Inc., a leader in the field of home furnishings. David was admired by all who knew him and will be sorely missed by his family and business colleagues. The world was a better place with him in it. Their original graves were near the Alhambra but were later moved into the Capilla Real down in town. Although they have more elaborate monuments above on the main floor, their bodies are interred in plain sarcophagi in the crypt. They were apparently personally modest and very devout; in life they used the title "their Catholic majesties."

But my psychotherapist had urged me to start writing down my conversations with people about what had happened with Jenna (instead of, as she put it, "just letting the wheels spin"), and I had decided to follow her advice. Enough with the endless whimpering. Time for some hard-nosed research.

title: GAS STATIONS CHARGED

title: Dog-Waste Management
description: The DNA of Dog Dirt Twenty-five hundred tons. That's how much manure was produced every day by the 200,000 horses that moved people and goods around New York City in the late 19th century. Much of the manure went uncollected, which posed a terrible problem. (This is to say nothing of the horse urine, the deafening clatter of hooves or the carcasses left to rot in the street.) The manure was so widespread and smelly and unsanitary that brownstones were built with their entrances on the second floor so that homeowners might rise above it.

title: Freakonomics

I find it difficult to accept that Roberts "could eat pretty much whenever and whatever he wanted"without gaining weight,unless he was already on a diet of 1,000 calories or less. In spite of what we may wish to believe, calories do count.

description: SIEGEL--Seymour S. CEO of Blue Ridge Farms, 1961-2004. Seymour Siegel was founder of Blue Ridge Farms, Inc., the largest deli salad production facility in the country. He started in the back of a 550 square foot store on East 79th Street in Manhattan in 1951. Mr. Siegel left behind a refrigerated food facility that covered over nine acres in Brooklyn as well as a distribution center in Florida. Blue Ridge Farms employs in excess of 600 poeple and sells products throughout the United States, Caribbean and Canada. At the time of his death Mr. Siegel was 76 years old. The cause of death was sudden systems failure. Mr. Siegel was born in Brooklyn, on June 6, 1929, to immigrant Russian parents. He was truly a self-made man who loved life and loved his family. Mr. Siegel was a 32nd degree Mason and a member of the Shrine. Mr. Siegel is survived by his wife, June, of 55 years; his two sons, Richard and Jeffrey, and Jeffrey's wife Sandra; six grandchildren, Marissa, Jessica, Louis, Caroline, Sara and Rebecca; and his two brothers, Martin and Joseph; as well as numerous nephews and nieces.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Oct. 2-Oct. 8; ART
description: Big exhibitions command the spotlight in the fall, but there are lots of interesting small ones, too. "YINKA SHONIBARE SELECTS WORKS FROM THE PERMANENT COLLECTION," which opens at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum on Thursday, is likely to be one. Mr. Shonibare was born in London, grew up in Nigeria and has an international career. Movement between cultures is a theme of his own art, and he explores it in this show that he has put together from the Cooper-Hewitt's holdings. Many of the objects once belonged to Amy, Eleanor and Sarah Hewitt, the globe-trotting sisters who founded the museum. And with its exotic souvenirs, travel diaries and prints of early flying devices, the show is about the pleasures and tensions of making the world your own. 2 East 91st Street, Manhattan, (212)849-8400.

Bloomberg's City
description: On a brilliant Sunday afternoon last month, Mayor Michael Bloomberg came to Lenox Avenue in Harlem to march in the annual African-American Day Parade. As he and his supporters prepared to step out into the street, a phalanx of marchers led by Fernando Ferrer, Bloomberg's Democratic challenger in the coming mayoral election, appeared behind him. Ferrer was flanked by leading black figures, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, gadfly and provocateur. Suddenly the rivets began to pop on the mayor's smoothly machined schedule. The parade organizer bizarrely, but very insistently, demanded that Bloomberg march alongside his own challenger. The mayor, flushed, said, "I'm here to march with my friends." Harlem is not friendly territory for a white Republican officeholder. Was there a racial subtext? It wasn't clear. The crowd grew denser and more turbulent, squeezing Bloomberg and his entourage to the edge of the street. "Run, Freddy, run!" came the cry from behind. The mayor, throttled, sidelined, stood with his arms crossed for five, six, seven minutes and said. . .nothing. He said absolutely nothing, and the incident, the nonincident, melted away.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: GALAPAGOS ISLANDS, ECUADOR
description: OFF NORTH SEYMOUR ISLAND, MAY 25, 2005 -- Jon Harrison, 23, a mergers and acquisitions adviser from London: "I always wanted to go to the Galpagos so I thought I'd blow the budget a bit. It's a great to be in a place that isn't a zoo, or a Sea World, where you jump in the water and within five minutes there are four or five sea lions swimming around, playing games with you. The frigate birds always follow the boats; the sun was going down and I was just relaxing, watching them. They were hovering maybe two or three feet above my face as we churned across the sea. To be that close to the birds was quite a unique moment. It summed up all the reasons why I'd wanted to take a break and refresh myself, to see new things and recharge my batteries."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRMAN, ELINOR
description: EHRMAN--Elinor. 83, died Saturday, September 10, in Westport, CT. She had a long, distinguished career in marketing and public relations. Her first job after college was staff aide to the Manhattan Project. After the war, Ms. Ehrman was hired by "Time" magazine and prestigious public relations agencies including Burson Marsteller as Executive Vice President. Ms. Ehrman resided in Westport, CT, and Hancock, ME, and served as trustee on a number of boards including her alma mater, The College of Wooster, and Sloan-Kettering Hospital. She is survived by godchildren, Gail, Bradley and William Stevenson, Laurie Kelly and several cousins.

title: In Newark, Rustic Beauty In African Pots

For those of us with little knowledge of African cultural traditions, there is the pure aesthetic quality of these richly textured objects. But there is also, for more experienced viewers, the utilitarian quality -- their practical and ceremonial function in traditional African societies.

title: Doctors in Schools
description: Mark, a doctor in Santa Rosa, Calif., writes after my Sunday column about health: Part of the solution to our national health care disgrace, at least for children, would be the promotion of school-based health centers (SBHCs). Here in Santa Rosa, Calif., there is a shining example at the Roseland Childrens Health Center. The RCHC, located on the Roseland Elementary School in the poorest part of town, is celebrating its 10th anniversary. During its ten years of operation it has raised immunization rates from 30 percent to 90 percent and has cut the rate of iron-deficiency anemia in half. The RCHC has been recognized by the American Academy of Pediatrics, as well as state and local government. The RCHC (and other school based health centers) also addresses the obstacles you described in todays column: 90 percent of the families are non- (or limited-) English speakers; many do not have cars; many parents can not get away from work easily. But they all manage to get their kids to school, so it makes sense to have health care facilities readily available at schools.

title: Worthy Canadian Initiative
description: Stephen scoffs at the idea of emulating Canadas health system, writing: I suggest you read the editorial column in this weeks Barrons,which addresses the enumerable shortcomings of the Canadian healthcare system that you so heartily applaud. If you believe that the United States, as well as the rest of the world, can provide universal, government-financed, quality health care,you are deluding yourself. We and the rest of the world,will no sooner be able to do that than we will be able to provide universally guaranteed, meaningful retirement benefits (social security) or universally paid, quality education. Until we explore alternative means of financing these so called rights and cost-effective, alternative ways to deliver these services, the only way to contain their costs will be rationing. Those that will suffer will be the ones you (and most of us) want to help the most. The answer in health care, as in retirement and education, is not in socializing the costs.

Discovering the Beatles, they decide to reinvent themselves as a modern-day British Invasion-style band, complete with horrendous wigs and psychedelic shirts. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, SEYMOUR S.
description: SIEGEL--Seymour S. CEO of Blue Ridge Farms, 1961-2004. Seymour Siegel was founder of Blue Ridge Farms, Inc., the largest deli salad production facility in the country. He started in the back of a 550 square foot store on East 79th Street in Manhattan in 1951. Mr. Siegel left behind a refrigerated food facility that covered over nine acres in Brooklyn as well as a distribution center in Florida. Blue Ridge Farms employs in excess of 600 poeple and sells products throughout the United States, Caribbean and Canada. At the time of his death Mr. Siegel was 76 years old. The cause of death was sudden systems failure. Mr. Siegel was born in Brooklyn, on June 6, 1929, to immigrant Russian parents. He was truly a self-made man who loved life and loved his family. Mr. Siegel was a 32nd degree Mason and a member of the Shrine. Mr. Siegel is survived by his wife, June, of 55 years; his two sons, Richard and Jeffrey, and Jeffrey's wife Sandra; six grandchildren, Marissa, Jessica, Louis, Caroline, Sara and Rebecca; and his two brothers, Martin and Joseph; as well as numerous nephews and nieces.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ballet Theater Director Takes Hong Kong Post
description: John Meehan, the artistic director of education and training at American Ballet Theater, has been appointed artistic director of the Hong Kong Ballet, effective July. Mr. Meehan, 55, has led Ballet Theater's Studio Company since 1997. "It has been a wonderful eight years," he said, but "I miss having a real budget to put together a season and having a long-term aesthetic goal that will impact the dance community." Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director of Ballet Theater, and Clinton Luckett, an artistic associate, will manage the Studio Company for its 2005-6 season. Mr. Meehan will replace Stephen Jefferies, a former principal dancer with the Royal Ballet who has led the Hong Kong Ballet since 1996. "The board felt it's time for a change," Helen Ng, the chief executive officer of the Hong Kong Ballet, said in an e-mail message. Mr. Jefferies said that he was unsure of his plans. Mr. Meehan said that he planned to infuse the Hong Kong Ballet's repertory with classic one-act ballets. "One of my goals is to try and find how Chinese culture can make its own stamp on the art form," he said. ERIKA KINETZ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, BURRILL, KATHLEEN R. F.
description: GRIFFIN-BURRILL-Kathleen R. F. Professor Emeritus of Turkish Studies at Columbia University, passed away suddenly following cardiac arrest in Seattle, Washington (USA), on September 18th. She was 81. Born in Canterbury, England, on March 8th, 1924, she worked for the British Council for over eight years, including five years on their staff in Turkey. Following her marriage in 1955 to Claude W. Burrill, she came to New York, where she obtained her PhD from Columbia University, with a dissertation on "The Quatrains of Nesimi, Fourteenth-century Hurufi". From 1957 until her retirement in 1999, Professor Burrill published works on folk, Ottoman and modern Turkish literature, as well as teaching courses at Columbia University on modern and Ottoman Turkish language and literature, and Islamic civilization, and serving as Chair of the Department of Middle East Languages and Cultures from 1985 to 1990. She was active and held posts in numerous professional associations, including the American Turkish Society (Board of Directors, Honorary Vice President 1974-1989), the Middle East Studies Association (Founding Fellow in 1967, Director 1974 -1976), the American Association of Teachers of Turkic Languages (Founding co-member, President and most recently President Emeritus), the Turkish Studies Association (Founding member and Director 19741976), and the Institute of Turkish Studies (Founding Associate, Governing Board Member and Secretary-Treasurer). In order to be near family, she moved to Seattle in April 2001, from Princeton, NJ, where she had resided since her divorce in 1991. She is survived by her daughter, Jane Burrill Santiago, and son-in-law, Bart Santiago, who were with her at the time of her death, as well as by her elder daughter, Anne Burrill; son-in-law, Alberto Noriega Guerra; and her three grandchildren, Paloma, Roberto and Aygul, who live in Belgium but had all visited her during the summer. Over the years, she has touched many lives on different continents and will be dearly missed. Her ashes will be taken "home" to England for final burial, alongside her beloved parents.

Officers apprehended the man, James Kahnis, 31, of 15 Joni Drive, about 1:20 a.m. after receiving reports that he was behaving irrationally, the police said. Mr. Kahnis's father reported that his son had run from home after saying that people were after him. Officers searching for Mr. Kahnis found him nearby with his father. As officers handcuffed Mr. Kahnis, he slumped and stopped breathing, the police said. He was taken to the John T. Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, where he was pronounced dead. An autopsy is scheduled to determine the cause of death.

description: Forget about the Darkness and the Electric Six. (If you haven't already.) For hard-rock ridiculousness, Nickelback is tough to beat. "All the Right Reasons" is another brash but sullen CD with more of the worst rock lyrics ever recorded: "Cause this was it, like flicking on a switch/It felt so good I almost drove into the ditch." The nostalgic ballad "Photograph" is a rising hit, but the band is more fun when it's going fast, and the singer Chad Kroeger is more funny when he's getting mad. Yet there's a new layer of perspective on her magnificent third album, "Extraordinary Machine" (Epic/Clean Slate). "I think he let me down when he didn't disappoint me," she admits in "Get Him Back." As she plunges into her latest miseries, her music finds something droll in the cycle of love and betrayal.

title: Arts, Briefly; Another Win for CBS
description: CBS won the second Friday of the fall television season in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49, as it did the previous week. According to Nielsen's estimates, CBS's math-loving criminal procedural "Numbers" was the night's most-watched program, with 11.23 million viewers. Earlier that night, Week 2 of "Ghost Whisperer" drew 10.7 million, which was down from its premiere, but outpaced what "Joan of Arcadia" delivered in the same time period in 2004. Sandwiched between "Numbers" and "Ghost Whisperer," in the 9 p.m. hour, "Threshold" lagged behind its fellow CBS shows. It brought in an audience of 8.33 million, and beat two episodes of ABC's "Hope & Faith" in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic by only a tenth of a ratings point. NBC's two new Friday night shows, "Three Wishes" and "Inconceivable," sank from their already low premiere numbers from the previous Friday, attracting 6.44 million and 4.64 million, respectively. title: Gabrieli Is More Than the Sum of His Brasses
description: Modern brass ensembles love to make hay with the majestic antiphonal music of the Italian composer Giovanni Gabrieli, and no one could blame them. But the bold gleaming sonorities that such contemporary groups produce were a far cry from what Andrew Parrott had in mind as he opened the eighth season of his New York Collegium on Friday night with a program devoted to Gabrieli's music. Mr. Parrott instead naturally packed his period with the brass instruments that Gabrieli wrote for in late-16th- and early-17th-century Venice. There were, to be precise, eight sackbuts and four cornetts happily ensconced among the other instruments, pouring their distinctly mellower and more lyrical tones into the generously vaulted space of St. Bartholomew's Church.

6 Years On, Wryly Dissecting Heartaches
description: With her low, melancholy voice and the tortured conscience of her lyrics, Fiona Apple never seemed cut out for comedy. But in six years between albums, Ms. Apple, 28, has grown into a wry self-consciousness. Her romances are still a shambles, and she painstakingly splits the blame between her lovers and herself. Yet there's a new layer of perspective on her magnificent third album, "Extraordinary Machine" (Epic/Clean Slate). "I think he let me down when he didn't disappoint me," she admits in "Get Him Back." As she plunges into her latest miseries, her music finds something droll in the cycle of love and betrayal.

title: Upon Return, Many Find Solace at Church

title: Macabre Clues Advance Inquiry in Bali Attacks
description: KUTA, Indonesia, Monday, Oct. 3 - In the first 24 hours after a series of bombs killed 22 people in a restaurant on a busy street and in two beachfront restaurants five miles away, investigators in Bali made rapid progress on Sunday, in part owing to a macabre bit of luck. As they sifted through bodies and body parts, they say, they found the heads of three men and three sets of legs, with no middles, the forensic signature of suicide bombings. One head was more than 75 feet from the rest of the body.

The police said five masked men, at least three of whom were armed, boarded the boat at 7:35 p.m. and forced their way into the money room. The police said the men took an undetermined amount of cash and fled west in a vehicle on Manhattan Avenue. About 350 passengers were aboard at the time of the robbery. No injuries were reported, the police said.

Billboard, which has been keeping an eye on this project since 2000, said the play deals with two competitive brothers who dislike each other intensely. When their father takes them to a family cabin for the first time since there were children, it turns out to be haunted by the father's two older brothers who loathed and killed each other there. "And they speak to the audience, and they sing to the audience," Mr. Mellencamp said. title: Arts, Briefly; 'Flightplan' Tops Box Office Again
description: Although five films opened or expanded their release this weekend, last week's reigning No. 1 retained its top spot at the box office. "Flightplan" (Buena Vista), an airplane thriller starring Jodie Foster, left, took in $15 million in estimated ticket sales, bringing its cumulative gross to $46 million. The film received some vociferous criticism last week when three unions representing flight attendants called for its boycott because they believed their members were depicted as rude and unsympathetic. "Serenity" (Universal), opened at No. 2 with sales of $10.1 million, according to studio estimates. The film was directed by Joss Whedon, known for the "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" television series. "Corpse Bride" (Warner Brothers), featuring the voices of Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter, dropped to No. 3 with $9.7 million in estimated receipts, bringing its cumulative sales to $32.9 million. The critically acclaimed "History of Violence" (New Line) expanded from 14 theaters to 1,340 and landed at No. 4 with $8.2 million. "Into the Blue" (Sony), a diving thriller starring Paul Walker and Jessica Alba, opened at No. 5 with $7 million. Over all, the box office is down 14.5 percent compared to last weekend and 25 percent compared to the same time last year. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, DAVID R.
description: KAHN--David R. In his 47th year. Loving husband of Susy; adoring father of Teddy and Daisy; beloved son of Joan and Mike Kahn, and son-in-law of Eva Rotmistrovsky and Hector Rotmistrovsky; and loving brother of Stefanie and Douglas Kahn; cherished uncle of Lauren, Michael and Daniel Kahn; adored nephew of Stanley Kahn and Gladys and Jerome Wiesenthal, his cousins Gary Kahn, Andrew and Billie Wiesenthal, Douglas Wiesenthal, Amy and Michael Liss and Richard Rotmistrovsky. We deeply mourn the loss of our much loved David, in whose company we reveled. David Kahn was the President and Chief Executive Officer of Croscill, Inc., a leader in the field of home furnishings. David was admired by all who knew him and will be sorely missed by his family and business colleagues. The world was a better place with him in it. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Israeli Defense Fund or the Duke Eye Center.

title: Mr. Putin's Clouded Promise
description: President Vladimir Putin sent out intentionally murky signals last week about the future of democracy in Russia. He said he saw no need to change the Constitution so that he could run for a third term in 2008. But he also promised a fawning questioner that he would not disappear. That promise had a backward thrust to it, much like the Soviet-style parades earlier this year, the jailing of Mr. Putin's political opponents and the steady narrowing of press freedoms. Now, as Russia faces the most basic test of its democratic progress -- holding real elections -- Mr. Putin seems determined to pull the strings.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Gunfight After Shooting
description: A police officer got into a gun battle yesterday with a man who had just wounded a 15-year-old boy in Bushwick, the police said. The gunman unloaded his revolver at the officer, another officer and a sergeant who had been patrolling the area in a van, the police said. The gunman and three friends had been tossed out of a christening party at 917 Broadway earlier and shot the boy as he left the party about 12:25 a.m., the police said. The officers and the sergeant heard the shots, responded, and ordered the gunman to drop his gun. After the man shot at the police, one of the officers returned fire and hit him in the chest and the leg, the police said. The man, whom the police did not identify yesterday, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was listed in critical condition yesterday. The boy was treated and released from the same hospital. The gunman and the three other men were arrested. Charges were pending yesterday, the police said.

description: FURST--Batya. Died Sunday, October 2nd, in Israel, where she had resided for 32 years. Beloved wife of Moshe for 58 years. Dear sister of Charlie Bick, Annie Berliner, Shirley Motechin and the late Rabbi Moshe Bick. Loving mother of Zev (Sandy), Malki (Dov Cymbalista) and Aryeh (Debi). title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIBNER, DAVID
description: DIBNER--David. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of David Dibner of Wilton, CT, a long-standing active member of the organization. Mr. Dibner served in many capacities on the regional and national board of directors and was a life trustee of the Board of Regents and a member of the Technion International Board of Governors. An engineer and accomplished businessman, he followed his family's tradition of commitment to Israel's technological edge and excellence in science education. He established the Bern Dibner Library in the Technion's William Davidson Faculty of Industrial Engineering and Management, in memory of his father, who had a long history of support for the Technion and a passion for the history of science and technology. A Technion Guardian who reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel, Mr. Dibner received a Technion honorary fellowship in 2001. We extend our condolences to his wife Frances; children Brent and Relly Dibner; Daniel and Victoria Dibner; and Mark and Rachel Dibner; and grandchildren. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Exec. V.P. Stanley Shirvan, NY Metropolitan Chapter Chair Nancy Gad-Harf, New York Metropolitan Regional Dir.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Monitors For Ukraine-Moldova Border
description: The European Union agreed to dispatch monitors along the border between Ukraine and Moldova, including the frontier with the unrecognized separatist enclave of Trans-Dniester. Beginning Dec. 1, 50 European customs and border officers, working in mobile teams, will conduct operations and training intended to reduce smuggling, arms trafficking and other crimes along a border that has become notorious for them. President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine and President Vladimir Voronin of Moldova requested the mission in part to resolve the conflict with Trans-Dniester, which declared its independence in the 1990's and has been supported, at least tacitly, by Russia.
