The People Speak (Shout, Actually) on Brooklyn Arena Project
description: Simmering tensions over a sweeping development project in Brooklyn erupted last night at a public hearing, as opponents and supporters took turns applauding, booing and interrupting one another. The meeting exposed deep divisions between residents who want jobs and housing and those who fear the traffic that the project might bring, as well as a host of other problems.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.S. Soldiers Kill 4 Policemen
description: American soldiers killed four Afghan policemen and wounded another in a firefight in Kandahar Province when they mistook them for Taliban insurgents, the provincial governor said. It was the second incident in recent weeks involving American forces and the Afghan police force. The clash came after a week of violence that included five suicide bomb attacks on international and Afghan personnel and the killing of three pro-government clerics. The American soldiers were on patrol in Maywand on Monday night when they came close to an Afghan police checkpoint, said the governor, Asadullah Khalid. "The police did some firing, and the coalition did not understand there was a police post there," he said. The Americans opened fire. An American military spokeswoman said she had no information on the case. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: A Modern-Age Mnage  Trois
description: Given that the subject of "Three of Hearts: A Postmodern Family" is a contemporary New York mnage  trois, the director, Susan Kaplan, and her executive producer, David Friedson, could have made an inane, smirky documentary.

title: A Challenge for Six Days: Planning Mississippi's Coast
description: Architects and urban planners have been known to pull all-nighters wrapping up big presentations. But the group of 200 who emerged bleary-eyed on Monday in Biloxi, Miss., had struggled with an unusually daunting task: rebuilding the state's entire coastline.

title: Just Off the Aisle at the Movies
description: MAYBE someone will someday figure out the confounding formula for why some restaurants are full while others are empty. I imagine this person as an older Mitteleuropean fellow scrawling equations on a blackboard. And just after he fills in that last elusive variable he drops his stub of chalk.

title: Tax Advisers to Bush Prepare 2 Overhaul Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - President Bush's tax advisory commission agreed on Tuesday to recommend two alternative plans, both of which would limit or eliminate almost all existing tax deductions, including those for state and local income and property taxes.

title: Faulty Hotel Count Adds to Complaints Against Red Cross
description: The Red Cross's failure to provide an accurate tally of the hurricane evacuees living in hotels, thus grossly overstating the cost to the government, could further undercut its efforts to reassure the public that it has adequate systems to account for the $1.2 billion it has collected for the relief effort.

title: Leading by (Bad) Example
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - A delegation of Iraqi judges and journalists abruptly left the U.S. today, cutting short its visit to study the workings of American democracy. A delegation spokesman said the Iraqis were "bewildered" by some of the behavior of the Bush administration and felt it was best to limit their exposure to the U.S. system at this time, when Iraq is taking its first baby steps toward democracy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Agrees To April Election
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi grudgingly agreed to an April 9 date for the next national elections. The date had been suggested on Monday by Romano Prodi, left, the opposition center-left candidate, after he won nearly three-quarters of some four million votes in the nation's first primary over the weekend. Mr. Berlusconi, whose center-right governing coalition is behind in the polls, agreed to the date, saying the interior minister had determined April 9 as the only possible date. Several of Mr. Berlusconi's political allies had also called for him to accept that date. But he rejected Mr. Prodi's call for national and local elections to be held on the same day and set the local elections for May. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: New Storm Measures as Most Intense Ever for Atlantic Basin
description: Hurricane Wilma, which appeared headed toward CancAon, Mexico, and possibly the Gulf Coast of Florida by this weekend, intensified into the most powerful storm ever recorded in the Atlantic Ocean basin today, but forecasters said its path remained unpredictable.

title: Panelist on Levees Faults Army Corps Budget Cuts
description: Budget cuts have cost the Army Corps of Engineers crucial scientific expertise that might have helped it to prevent levee failures in New Orleans and to do a better job restoring the city's battered flood protection system, members of a panel of prominent outside experts said.

title: Nominee Backed Ban on Abortion in 1989 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - Harriet E. Miers, the Supreme Court nominee, disclosed on Tuesday a 1989 survey in which she supported banning abortion except to protect the life of the pregnant woman. The disclosure alarmed abortion rights supporters but failed to assuage the concerns of some conservative Republicans.

title: Naughty Harry: Lawyering Without a License
description: I was just coming to grips with the idea that a Supreme Court nominee doesn't need to have any experience for the job.

title: Ulcer Drug Challenge
description: AstraZeneca said yesterday that Ranbaxy Laboratories of India had applied to United States regulators to make a version of AstraZeneca's ulcer drug Nexium.

title: Round and Round the Faces Go
description: "Says a Lot," a 30-second commercial for Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, began running yesterday on cable and network television stations in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Nominee's Financial Disclosures Show Worth of Less Than $1 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - Harriet E. Miers worked as a corporate lawyer in Texas for years before serving in a high-ranking White House job, but she never vaulted into the ranks of the superrich.

title: His Family and the Family
description: DETROIT, Oct. 18 - William Clay Ford Jr. was recently asked if it was fair to call him, as many have, a reluctant chief executive of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOOP, RAYMOND R.
description: KNOOP--Raymond R., 86. On October 17, 2005 passed away after a long and courageously fought battle with Parkinson's disease. Best known and recognized for his integrity, loyalty and ever giving personality; he was a true man in every sense of the word, respected and loved by all that knew him. He served as a ranking Dutch-born intelligence officer for the U.S. Army during World War II and was discharged with honors. He later became one of the founding principals of Empire State Chair Co., an industry leader in the design and production of commercial furniture. Beloved and devoted husband, father and grandfather he is survived by his wife of 54 years, Elisabeth, his children Henri (wife Pamela), Gregg (wife Lisa) and Clara (husband Michael) Felsher, and his grandsons Zachary and Jason. He is also survived by his sister Stella (husband Gerard) Los. Funeral Service Wednesday, October 19 at 10 A.M., at Community Synagogue of Rye. Interment Sharon Gardens. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Parkinson's Foundation, or The Simon Wiesenthal Center.

title: 4,468 Pounds of Wrestlers, and That Was Before Lunch
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a proposed provision for the Texas Constitution to ban same-sex marriage misstated the result of the 2004 presidential election in Harris County, which includes liberal-leaning Houston, and a correction in this space on Friday misstated the size of the county's electorate. President Bush won the county by 55 percent to 45 percent; Senator John Kerry did win Houston. Harris County accounts for 15 percent of the state's electorate, not 30 percent.

title: Study Finds Failure to File Malpractice Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - Federal health agencies routinely flout a requirement to report any cases in which they pay medical malpractice claims against the government, federal investigators said Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Michael R. Bloomberg's management style gave an incorrect attribution in some copies for a statement by an aide, recalling the way Mr. Bloomberg planned to handle his first meeting, at a banquet, with the Rev. Al Sharpton. It was William T. Cunningham, a senior adviser, not Edward Skyler, the mayor's communications director, who said: "He goes, 'If he's there, I'll shake his hand. It'll be over and done with."'

title: Alas, the unfreshened Cream
Grief Reveals Softer Side of the Nets' Jackson
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 18 - Yes, Marc Jackson's intimidating scowl, his bellowing voice and the way he throws his body around on the basketball court all come from an inner fire, one that is kindled by a rough upbringing in Philadelphia playing street ball against men who showed little mercy.

title: Saddam Hussein Goes on Trial for Crimes Against Humanity
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 19 - Iraqi judges and prosecutors assembled this morning in a heavily guarded compound in central Baghdad as Saddam Hussein and seven defendants prepared to face charges in a 1982 massacre, beginning the long process of public reckoning for the decades of brutal repression that Mr. Hussein brought to Iraq.

title: Towers Grow in Downtown Brooklyn
description: The resurgence of Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Williamsburg is well documented. But what is not as widely known is how well the downtown business district is doing, despite a still somewhat dog-eared appearance. What is more, the area is on the verge of a major transformation.

title: Meanwhile: When Britannia ruled the waves
Corrections
description: Two articles on Oct. 11 about the earthquake that struck India and Pakistan on Oct. 8 misstated the ownership of the Press Trust of India, a main source of initial information on casualties and damage. (The error also occurred in unrelated articles on April 18, and May 26.) The news agency is a nonprofit cooperative owned by India's newspapers, not state-owned or state-run.

title: Africa May Face Risk for Bird Flu, Officials Fear
description: ROME, Oct. 19 - As bird culls to control probable new outbreaks of bird flu started on farms in Russia and Macedonia, United Nations officials here warned today that their far larger concern was that the dreaded virus was on its way to East Africa, where the disease could be nearly impossible to control.

title: Keeping Special Ed on the Radar
description: ON a Friday afternoon in late September, with the nation riveted on Hurricane Rita, the New York City Department of Education quietly released the Hehir report, an independent evaluation of the city's special education system. The city paid a team of experts led by Thomas Hehir of Harvard $350,000 to find out how the mayor's 2003 reorganization of a long-troubled special ed system -- one that serves 154,000 students -- was doing.

title: J.P. Morgan reports 78% rise in profit
Hurricane Wilma grows into dangerous Category 5
Rising inflation fears bolster dollar's gains
Arts, Briefly; CBS and ABC Share the Spoils
description: The St. Louis Cardinals won in baseball, the St. Louis Rams lost in football. And for the fourth Monday in a row, CBS and ABC divided the ratings loot. CBS ranked first among total viewers; ABC was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49. ABC's margin of victory for "Monday Night Football" was smaller than usual, as sports fans also had Fox's postseason baseball to watch. CBS's "CSI: Miami" was, as usual, the most-watched program of Monday in Nielsen's estimates. It drew 17.21 million viewers. While the ratings of the other CBS shows -- "The King of Queens" (10.61 million), "How I Met Your Mother" (10.11 million) and "Out of Practice" -- were all at typical levels, "Two and a Half Men" delivered its largest audience (15.6 million) and best 18-to-49 numbers of the season so far. KATE AURTHUR

title: How a Big Investor Fell Into the Refco Deal
description: J. Christopher Flowers, a private equity investor with a penchant for making a killing on failed financial situations, had never heard of Phillip R. Bennett until he read last week about his ouster and the downfall of Mr. Bennett's company, Refco Inc., the commodities and futures brokerage giant.

title: Holiday Shopping Before the First Heating Bill
description: PARIS, Oct. 18 - Facing pressure from governments seeking to fight a possible bird flu epidemic, the Swiss drug maker Roche said Tuesday that it was willing to negotiate to allow outside companies to make its drug Tamiflu, which has been shown to fight avian influenza.

title: Restaurants Aren't Just for Eating
description: The new musical "Five Course Love" is a pleasantly fluffy if sometimes offensive vehicle, but a young actress named Heather Ayers turns it into a potentially star-making one. Her versatile, big-voiced performance in five roles might make Kristin Chenoweth want to check the rearview mirror. And the two men who share the stage with her, John Bolton and Jeff Gurner, are almost as engaging.

title: Hedging Their Bets in the Mayor's Race
description: In recent weeks, the trickle of Democrats endorsing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has turned more into a steady stream, with prominent local politicians like Brooklyn Borough President Marty Markowitz, former City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and City Councilwoman Eva Moskowitz lining up to endorse the Republican incumbent.

title: Court Rebuffs The Times Co. Over Lawsuit
description: A federal appeals court yesterday declined to reconsider a ruling that allowed a former Army bioterrorism expert to proceed with a defamation suit against The New York Times Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIXON, MARY HELLER
description: DIXON--Mary Heller. Of Scarsdale passed away on October 16, 2005. Mary is survived by her husband George, and her son George (G.J.), her brothers, Arthur & Brian Heller and her sister Catherine Lenihan. Family and friends may visit the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home in Scarsdale, NY, 914725-1137 on Wednesday and Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. A Mass will be on Friday at Our Lady of Fatima Church at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Mary's memory to Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, PO Box 650309, Dallas, TX 75265-0309. 1-800-462-9273.

title: Arts, Briefly; All-Star Double Album Planned for Hurricane Relief
description: Coldplay, Fats Domino, right, James Brown, Barbra Streisand, the Dave Matthews Band, Elton John, Brian Wilson, Sting, Gloria Estefan, Clint Black and others will be featured in a two-CD compilation to benefit victims of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, Billboard reported. The album, "Hurricane Relief: Come Together Now," is due in mid-November and will be a joint project by the four major record labels, the Recording Industry Association of America and the Concord Music Group. The album will feature "Heart of America," sung by Wynonna, Michael McDonald and Eric Bent, who are to perform the song before Game 3 of the World Series next week. Other highlights include a version of Eric Clapton's song "Tears in Heaven," originally recorded after the Asian tsunami last year with Velvet Revolver, Sir Elton, Mary J. Blige, Rod Stewart, Gwen Stefani, and Ozzy and Kelly Osbourne; "Come Together Now," written by the actress Sharon Stone with the songwriters Denise Rich, Damon Sharpe and Mark Feist, and performed by a cast of nearly 30 artists. Proceeds from the album will go to the American Red Cross, Habitat for Humanity and the MusiCares Hurricane Relief Fund. BEN SISARIO

title: Sleeping Pill Use by Youths Soars, Study Says
description: The use of sleeping pills among children and very young adults rose 85 percent from 2000 to 2004, in yet another sign that parents and doctors are increasingly turning to prescription medications to solve childhood health and behavioral problems.

title: Familiar Brahms and an Unaccustomed 'Four Seasons'
description: Some people go to concerts for the performers, others to hear what they are playing. The Cleveland Orchestra threw a little satisfaction in both directions on Monday night. Chen Yi's "Si Ji" was there to discover. Most of this audience at Carnegie Hall, to put it euphemistically, had heard Brahms before, including the First Symphony and the "Academic Festival Overture," both on this program.

title: Mainland affirms one-party rule
Tuition Rise Tops Inflation, but Rate Slows, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - Average college tuition grew more quickly than did overall inflation again this year, although the rate of increase slowed after a period of explosive growth, according to an annual survey released here Tuesday by the College Board.

title: Truth and Consequences
Corrections
description: Two articles on Oct. 11 about the earthquake that struck India and Pakistan on Oct. 8 misstated the ownership of the Press Trust of India, a main source of initial information on casualties and damage. (The error also occurred in unrelated articles on April 18, and May 26.) The news agency is a nonprofit cooperative owned by India's newspapers, not state-owned or state-run.

title: Tory veteran ousted in leadership fight
Mubarak Foe, Bravado Gone, Feels Smeared
description: CAIRO, Oct. 18 - Egypt's most prominent political opposition leader, whose defiance of President Hosni Mubarak won him a second-place finish in this nation's election for president last month, says he is the target of an orchestrated campaign to discredit and marginalize him.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles on Oct. 11 about the earthquake that struck India and Pakistan on Oct. 8 misstated the ownership of the Press Trust of India, a main source of initial information on casualties and damage. (The error also occurred in unrelated articles on April 18, and May 26.) The news agency is a nonprofit cooperative owned by India's newspapers, not state-owned or state-run.

title: Codey in Countdown to Avert Takeover of Child Services
description: TRENTON, Oct. 18 - With barely three months left in his term, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey is scrambling to avoid a court takeover of New Jersey's beleaguered child welfare agency.

title: Europeans Block French Move to Limit Global Trade Talks
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 18 - European foreign ministers rejected a French proposal on Tuesday to rein in the negotiating authority of Peter Mandelson, the European Union trade commissioner, keeping alive for now hopes of reaching a global trade agreement.

title: Corrections
description: Correction Appended

title: Thanks for the Memories. Let's Make More.
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 - Among the love letters, the marriage proposals and the tearful tributes scrawled on the side of Busch Stadium came a memo Tuesday that was written in bold black marker and punctuated with three exclamation points.

title: The Religious and the Greens Could Be an Influential Pair
description: GARRISON, N.Y. - FROM the restored gazebo overlooking the Hudson on the grounds of what used to be a Capuchin monastery, the river looks at once serene and bustling. Yes, you can sense the meditative stillness that has been a part of this place for decades, but there's a freight train rumbling across the west bank, a passenger train on the east. Looking north, you see the bristling fortress of West Point. Straight across is a river landing, outcrops of development poking out from the green forests. You can see a hawk swooping overhead and the faint splashes of orange signifying the late arrival of fall, and you can also feel the economic activity pushing at the river from all sides.

title: Witness Defends Broad Definition of Science
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 - A leading architect of the intelligent-design movement defended his ideas in a federal courtroom on Tuesday and acknowledged that under his definition of a scientific theory, astrology would fit as neatly as intelligent design.

title: A Nation and Its Newcomers, All in Flux
description: The most shocking image in David Grubin's "Destination America" is a headline from a Connecticut newspaper, The Bridgeport Telegram: "Stricter Immigration Laws Needed to Purify Stock of U.S. Population -- Davis," with an article written by James J. Davis, secretary of labor from 1921 to 1930.

title: Pasta Sauces With A West Village Pedigree
description: Il Mulino sauces, which draw on recipes from the long-established Il Mulino restaurant in Greenwich Village, have clean, bright flavors and the perfect texture for coating pasta. The marinara has a garlicky bite, and one taste of the pomodoro confirms that there is butter in it. Simmer either to slather on meatloaf or a steak, or add them to homemade meatballs or sausages. Use the marinara as the basis for a puttanesca or to spike a sauce for steamed mussels. Serve the pomodoro right from the jar as a dip or thin it and add cream for tomato soup.

title: Copper and cozy, a partner for art
Where, at Last, Ripeness Is Really All
description: As bejeweled and gowned cabaret princesses like Karen Akers, Andrea Marcovicci and Lumiri Tubo swanned across the stage of the Rose Theater on Monday evening, you could entertain the absurd illusion of New York as an unchanging cultural stage for the last four decades.

title: Number Overstated for Storm Evacuees in Hotels
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - The Red Cross and federal government said Tuesday that they had been significantly overreporting the number of Hurricane Katrina evacuees in hotels. Instead of 600,000 people, 200,000 remain in hotels, the charity said.

title: Stonehenge on the lawn? People will talk
Those Boys Are Back, as Timely as Ever
description: Trey Parker has a confession to make. "I've started confiding in people, other artists mostly, that I hate making 'South Park' and I always have," he said during a recent visit to New York. He continued: "It's super stressful. I'm always miserable. I want to kill myself every week."

title: Strong aftershocks hit South Asian quake region
Not Equal Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Audience for an Explicit Ad
description: A new billboard went up on Monday across Baltic Street from Public School 133 on the western fringe of Park Slope, Brooklyn. The sign is aimed at the drivers going by on busy Fourth Avenue, but the students at the school, who range from kindergarten to fifth grade, can also learn a lot from it.

title: A Military Role in Disaster Relief (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking the Ice Up North
description: NEW LONDON, Conn. - POLITICIANS and scientists may debate why the earth is warming, but the fact remains: the Arctic ice cap, estimates say, has shrunk by nearly half in the last 50 years.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe: Russia: Ministers Urge Diversification
description: Russia should invest its windfall oil profits in other sectors, particularly information technology, so the country's economy does not topple when the energy boom slows, two ministers said at an economic forum in Moscow. The meeting, a spinoff of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, focused on options for spending the $34 billion in Russia's stabilization fund. Aleksandr D. Zhukov, a deputy prime minister, said the government would direct resources at the high-technology sector and invest in roads, ports and airports. The minister of economic development and trade, German O. Gref, floated the idea of special economic zones for information technology and industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTSON, ELIZABETH KING
description: ROBERTSON--Elizabeth King, 53. Lizzy died October 12, 2005 from cancer, peacefully in her sleep at her home in Alameda, California. She is survived by many loving and devoted relatives, including her husband James Robertson, parents Henry L. King and Mary S. King, stepmother Margaret G. King, siblings Matthew, Katie, Andy & Ellie, stepbrothers Michael and Joseph, and eleven nieces and nephews. Lizzy will be remembered for her warmth, generosity of spirit and sense of humor. She will be greatly missed by her family and many friends. A private memorial service will be scheduled in the future.

title: South of Boston, Wary Officials Watch a Weakened Dam
description: BOSTON, Oct. 18 - Some 2,000 residents of Taunton, Mass., were unable to return to their homes on Tuesday because of fears that a deteriorating dam on a rain-swollen river could rupture and flood the city's downtown area.

title: Spain Seeks Arrest of 3 G.I.'s in Death of Spanish Journalist in Iraq
description: MADRID, Oct. 19 - A Spanish judge issued an international arrest order today for three American soldiers in connection with the death of a Spanish journalist killed in 2003 when an American tank fired at a hotel in Baghdad during the Army's advance on the Iraqi capital.

title: Queensboro Bridge Is Closed by Fire
description: Traffic on the Queensboro Bridgewas banned for almost four hoursTuesday when canvas sheetingused in sandblasting caught fireshortly after noon and five firefighterswere slightly injured. Thelower level of the bridge, at 59thStreet, reopened later in the afternoon,but the upper roadway wasclosed for the rest of the day andwas to be reopened at 5 a.m. Wednesday.Declared a four-alarm blaze,the fire drew 168 firefighters and39 units. Workers were paintingsteel beams on the upper levelwhen the fire broke out. "Weneeded a tremendous amount ofmanpower to get the water andthe hose up to extinguish the fire,"said the Fire Department'sQueens Borough commander, AssistantChief Robert F. Sweeney,according to The AssociatedPress. The bridge, designated anational landmark in 1973, is inthe middle of a major rehabilitationthat began in 1981 and isscheduled for completion in2009.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: All Bach, All the Time

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Not Equal Yet (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Defiant Hussein, Lashing Out at U.S., Goes on Trial
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 19 - Saddam Hussein arrived for the opening of his trial today a shadow, physically, of the merciless figure he cut in nearly a quarter of a century as Iraq's dictator. But scrawny, tieless, and in a store-bought suit provided by his American captors, he dominated the hearing with a display of defiance, saying he would not recognize the Iraqi court's authority because it was a pawn of the American occupation, "and all things that are based on a falsehood are false."

title: CHARLEMAGNE'S TABLECLOTH: A Piquant History of Feasting
Heart medicine bolsters Novartis
Police Group Urges Limit on Taser Use
description: An influential police research group is recommending new restrictions on the use of Tasers, the electric stun guns associated with nearly 140 deaths of people being taken into custody.

title: The Homeland Security Dole
description: The Senate has a final chance this week to reverse its shocking decision to shift antiterrorist grants away from endangered populated areas, to low-risk rural states whose lawmakers want another pork-barrel windfall. The Senate's approach is on the negotiating table with a far more preferable House measure that would better focus the resources on where the risks are. What is at stake in the negotiations is the nation's readiness to withstand terrorist attacks in its most vulnerable spots. Homeland security cannot be advanced by another split-the-difference compromise from Congress.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vote Narrows Tory Leadership Race To 3
description: Legislators from the opposition Conservatives voted to eliminate Kenneth Clarke, a former finance minister, from further balloting to choose a replacement for Michael Howard as party leader. The voting left David Davis, David Cameron and Liam Fox to face a second ballot among legislators tomorrow. The final choice between two of them will be made in a runoff to be voted on by all party members, with results expected in December. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: On eve of Saddam's trial, questions
Miers Hits Another Snag as Senators Fault Her Questionnaire
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 - The contentious nomination of Harriet E. Miers to the Supreme Court hit another snag this afternoon when both the Republican chairman and ranking Democrat of the Senate Judiciary Committee said her responses to senators' questions had thus far been unsatisfactory.

title: Barbecue in Brooklyn Can Mean Garden Burgers
description: Oh, to be a student in Brooklyn, especially a barbecue-loving one in the vicinity of Pig'N Out Barbeque, at 60 Henry Street (Orange Street). The owners -- from left above, John Tsakinis, Roderick Marino and Tomasz Surowka-- now offer a 20 percent discount to students between 11 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. (nonstudents get the discount between 11 a.m. and 4 p.m.) Monday through Friday. The owners, whose roots are in Greece, the Philippines and Poland, far from barbecue country, do not pretend to be barbecue purists, offering on a new menu effective next week Greek salads, chicken teriyaki and garden burgers along with St. Louis-style ribs, Carolina pulled-pork sandwiches, sweet potato fries and baked beans. Prices range from $3.50 for some starters to $135 for a feast that serves 10: (718)522-5547. FOOD STUFF

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Says River Plan Cheats Salmon
description: In a setback for the Bush administration, a federal appeals court in San Francisco rejected a federal plan to distribute water to farmers from the troubled Klamath River region in Oregon and California, ruling that more water must remain in the river for the coho salmon. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit sided with conservation groups, commercial fishermen and the Yurok and Hoopa Valley Indian tribes in returning the plan to a federal court to be reworked. The groups had sued over the 10-year plan, arguing that it favored irrigation over sustaining the coho, a threatened species. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Rescuing Little Nemo, warts and all
The Only Bush I Trust is My Own
Back on the Road
description: American corporations have to run leaner and meaner in the global competitive environment. By agreeing to let General Motors trim the well-above-average health benefits it offers, the United Auto Workers negotiators showed that they are willing to be active participants, rather than merely speed bumps, on the road to globalization. We hope that rank-and-file union members approve the deal, trusting that accepting less now may mean more later on.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a temporary custody decision involving a 4-year-old girl abandoned in Queens gave an incorrect location from relatives for the home where she is staying, and attributed a reference to it erroneously. The home is in West Babylon, on Long Island, not in College Point, Queens. John B. Mattingly, New York City's children's services commissioner, mentioned the home at a news conference without specifying its location.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSCOVICI, WILLY G., M.D.
description: MOSCOVICI--Willy G., M.D. On October 18, 2005. We mourn the death of Dr. Willy Moscovici an outstanding physician, an innovator in his field and fully dedicated to his patients. He was loved by his family, friends, and his patients. He will be missed by all. He leaves behind his wife Elisa, daughter Rodica and her husband Sergio, granddaughters, Alexandra, Karen, and Andrea, and their husbands, Graham, Jeff, and Sal, and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell - the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, (81st Street), Thursday 11:30 A.M.

title: A Vineyard Prodigy Too Young to Drink
description: PROSSER, Wash. - JUST after sunrise, and Victor Palencia was examining barrel samples inside the cellar, basically a cold-storage shed with the just-born feel of this blue-collar wine country, a place where the Subway sandwich shop sports a sign that says, "Welcome wine enthusiasts." He sniffed, ran the wine over his tongue. Sniffed again, held the juice up to the light.

title: Many Liberian Women See the Ballot Box as a Step Up
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 14 - Clutching her voter registration card in one hand and leaning on a second-story balcony railing with the other, Mabel Tobee waited to vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PADER, ELMER, M.D.
description: PADER--Elmer, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of esteemed colleague and longtime friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. Barry Stimmel, MD, Pres. Elliot Rayfield, MD, V.P. Steven Itzkowitz, MD, Sec'y Martin Goldstein, MD, Treas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, PATRICK F.
description: KELLY--Patrick F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Patrick F. Kelly, associated with The Times from May 1976 until retiring in January 1989.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: French General Suspended For Ivorian Death
description: France has suspended the former commander of French peacekeepers in Ivory Coast over accusations of a cover-up following the death earlier this year of an Ivorian man detained by French troops serving in the West African nation. Defense Minister Michle Alliot-Marie suspended Henri Poncet, the four-star general who is now commander of France's southwest military district, late Monday, according to news reports. Two other officers were also suspended, and an investigation is under way. About 4,000 French soldiers are serving alongside 6,000 United Nations peacekeepers in the former French colony, divided since rebels tried to oust the president in 2002. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Saddam and Iraq on Trial
description: The opportunity created by the trial of Saddam Hussein to introduce the rule of law and the idea of national reconciliation into Iraq has been largely squandered even before the courtroom proceedings begin. At almost every turn, ill-considered decisions by the United States and Iraq's dominant Shiite-religious and Kurdish-nationalist parties have put politics and score-settling first. The cost has been an indifference to legal scrupulousness, as well as a failure to distinguish between pursuing the specific crimes of a dictator that must be punished in a court and waging a collective vendetta by Kurdish and Shiite victims against the Sunni Arabs who were once their oppressors.

About 4 p.m., the train crew reported that someone had shot at the locomotive, breaking a window and hitting someone, said John K. Enright, a spokesman for Conrail. Light-rail service was disrupted for about two hours in the south end of Jersey City and in Bayonne, said Dan Stessel, a New Jersey Transit spokesman.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Sands Point: Body Of Slain Woman Is Identified
description: The authorities said yesterday that the body of a young woman found dead in the affluent Nassau County town Sands Point last week was a 24-year-old mother of two. The woman, Elisabeth Parisi, of 10 Fawn Place, Mastic Beach, was discovered bludgeoned to death on Saturday in a weedy area of Hoffstots Lane in Sands Point, the police said. They said Ms. Parisi had been identified by fingerprint records from a previous arrest in a Suffolk County domestic violence case and by a tattoo she had. They refused to discuss her arrest but said that on Monday, investigators had released a sketch of Ms. Parisi and a photo of the tattoo, a blue flower. Ms. Parisi's brother, Paul Parisi, 25, also of Mastic Beach, said investigators told him that they wanted to question Ms. Parisi's boyfriend, Edgar Sanchez. Mr. Parisi said his sister was a homemaker who cared for her two children, a girl, 5, and 4-month-old boy.

title: Loire Reds Liked It Hot

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fresh Shooting In Restive Southern City
description: New clashes erupted in the southern Russian region of Kabardino-Balkaria as security forces continued to search for militants who attacked the regional capital, Nalchik, on Thursday. The police sealed off parts of the city and ordered schools evacuated, as gunfire reverberated through the city. At least one man suspected of taking part in the attack was killed, according to officials cited by official Russian news agencies. Two others who had been wounded last week -- one a civilian, the other a suspected fighter -- died in a Nalchik hospital, raising to at least 138 the official death toll in the violence that many have attributed to an ominous widening of Russia's conflict against separatist rebels in Chechnya. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REAVIS, THETIS TOULIATOU
description: REAVIS--Thetis Touliatou, of New York and Stonington, CT, unexpectedly on October 14, 2005. Adoring of and adored by her daughter and son-in-law, Helen D. ("Heidi") Reavis, and Steven Engel, and loving of and loved by her sister and brother-in-law, Diana and Roy Vagelos, her nieces and nephews, Ellen Masseur, Andrew Vagelos, Cynthia Roberts, Randall Vagelos and their families, her niece and nephews, Cate Reavis, David Reavis, Jamie Reavis and their families, as well as the Andris family, the Copsinis family, the Eitel family, the Engel family, the Harocopos family, the Touliatos family, and numerous other close relatives, friends and colleagues. A graduate of Smith College (Phi Beta Kappa) and The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, Thetis spent her career in foreign policy and education and for 24 years worked at The Foreign Policy Association, most recently as its Vice President, Public Affairs. She was actively involved with many organizations including The Women's City Club of New York, UNIFEM (United Nations Development Fund for Women) and The Smith College Club of New York City. Thetis is already sorely missed. No one who knew Thetis was left untouched by her generosity, love, friendship, kindness and intelligence. A family service will be held in Stonington, Connecticut. A memorial service to honor Thetis will be held in NYC later this year. At that time, the family will communicate with respect to contributions in lieu of flowers.

description: The Supreme Court stripped Gen. World Briefing | Americas: U.S. And Cuban Policies Hurt Families, Rights Group Says
description: The United States will not let a Cuban migr visit her dying father in Cuba. A Cuban-American in the armed forces is barred from visiting his sons in Cuba while on leave from Iraq. A Cuban scientist is permanently banned from visiting her son in Argentina on the ground that her brain is "the property" of the government. These are just a few of the cases cited in a report by the New York-based group Human Rights Watch that condemned travel restrictions imposed by both the United States and Cuba. The report noted that Fidel Castro had long used travel restrictions to control defections, silence critics and punish people. But it also faulted the Bush administration for tightening rules on travel to Cuba last year, on the ground that trips home by Cuban expatriates were providing the government with much needed hard currency. Cubans living in the United States may now visit members of their immediate family just once every three years. "The policies on both sides have had a devastating impact on a large number of people," said Daniel Wilkinson, a spokesman for Human Rights Watch.

When the girl tried to walk away, the man punched her in the face and pulled her into the van at knifepoint, then raped her and stole her cellphone and a small amount of cash, the police said. Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, GEORGE MUNSON
description: HARRIS--George Munson. George Munson Harris died in the loving embrace of his wife Suzanne and surrounded by his children and grandchildren on October 18, 2005. He was born October 14, 1924, in Albany, NY, attended Albany Academy and Lawrenceville School, and received his BA from Princeton University in 1946. He was a Lieutenant JG in the US Navy, served in WWII on the USS Thompson, and was awarded a Purple Heart. George joined Wood Struthers in New York following graduation, then moved to San Antonio in the early 1950s and founded the brokerage firm, Harris & Company, with his friend George Knapp. He moved to Dittmar & Company in 1965, where he served on the Board of Directors. Dittmar merged with Loeb Rhoades in 1973, and there followed a succession of mergers until his retirement from Shearson Lehman Brothers in 1989. George was a learned collector of Western and American art and became partners with Don and Bettina Blair in a fine art gallery in Santa Fe, NM, where he and Suzanne maintained a second home. He was an accomplished tennis player, having been ranked nationally in college, and was a member of the United States Senior Golf Association. He and Suzanne toured the world with close friends, playing the finest golf courses in countries throughout Europe. George is survived by Suzanne, his wife of 44 years; by five children, Melanie Vavrek and her husband, Jerry, of Midland, TX, Stephanie Harris Wilson and her husband Scott of San Antonio, TX, George Harris, Jr. and his wife, Pat, of Midland, TX, Susan Clements Negley of San Antonio, TX, and Jamie Clements and his wife, Diana, of Austin, TX; and by 12 grandchildren, William Negley, Ashley Clements, Adam Vavrek, Zachary Vavrek, Kimberley Gates, Jamie Negley, Madison Clements, Suzanne Negley, Austen Clements, Georgia Gates, Noe Clements and Carolina Clements. Memorial service, Friday, October 21, 2005, 11:00 A.M. First Presbyterian Church 404 N. Alamo, San Antonio, TX. The Rev. Bryan Eckelmann officiating. Pallbearers: Dr. James W. Nixon, The Honorable William P. Clements, Jr., Jack Locke, James L. Hayne, Fred Lepick and Eugene L. Ames, Jr. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to Cancer Therapy and Research Center, 8122 Datapoint, Suite 600, San Antonio, TX 78229, First Presbyterian Church, 404 North Alamo, San Antonio, TX 78205 or Sunshine Cottage School for Deaf Children, 103 Tuleta, San Antonio, TX 78212. title: Arts, Briefly; Major Publishers Sue Google
description: Five large American publishing companies filed a lawsuit against Google yesterday, charging that the company's Google Print for Libraries program -- which plans to make searchable, digital copies of nearly all the books in five major research libraries -- violates the rights of the publishers under the federal Copyright Act. McGraw-Hill, Pearson Education, Penguin Group, Simon & Schuster and John Wiley & Sons filed a joint lawsuit in the Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeking a declaration that the Google Print for Libraries program violates copyright and requesting an injunction against the scanning of printed works without the permission of the copyright holder. The lawsuit is similar to one filed last month by three authors whose works are included in the University of Michigan library, one of the libraries whose collections Google plans to digitize. By filing a similar suit, the publishers put considerably more muscle behind the action against Google. Google has maintained that its program is covered by the fair use provision of copyright law and that it therefore does not need permission of the copyright holders for the library project. The program makes only small portions of a copyrighted text available to users online; Google likens the result to an electronic card catalog. EDWARD WYATT

title: The Power of the Atom, in a Gleaming Crystal of Iron
description: Andr Waterkeyn, a Belgian engineer, died this month at 88 as the renovation of the Atomium, his most famous design, neared completion. The structure, the Eiffel Tower of Brussels, was built for the 1958 World's Fair and proved so popular with tourists (if not critics) that it was kept on afterward. Part of an effort to promote atomic science, it depicts an iron crystal more than 300 feet tall: nine spheres, each about 60 feet in diameter, linked by tubes. In recent years its aluminum sheathing dulled and its frame rusted. The $33 million renovation has reclad the spheres in stainless steel and updated the interiors that are accessible to the public with a design that evokes the 50's. It is scheduled to reopen in February.

With the theater's packed schedule and its hyperkinetic boss, Valery Gergiev, the Mariinksy cannot have been a placid place to cut one's teeth. No wonder there is a whirling excitement to Mr. Noseda's gestures on the podium, at least as witnessed on Thursday night, when he returned to lead the New York Philharmonic in Avery Fisher Hall. NBC's "My Name Is Earl" (11.79 million) attracted the night's highest ratings in that demographic, and the network's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (14.12 million) brought in the second highest. ABC's "Commander in Chief" continued its run as the most popular show of the new season, with 15.95 million viewers. Thanks to "Chief," ABC placed second among viewers for the night. For the week that ended on Sunday, CBS topped the other networks in both total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds for the first time this season. (ABC had won the previous weeks in the age group advertisers value most.) CBS had six shows in the top 10 for the week: "CSI," "Without a Trace," "CSI: Miami," "NCIS," "Survivor" and "60 Minutes." title: Boone, N.C.
description: THE Appalachian Mountains of North Carolina were America's frontier when Daniel Boone hunted there during his mid-18th century wanderings. Boone would still recognize the beautiful Blue Ridge high country, where in the fall the hills are ablaze with color. But he might be surprised that his namesake town is a thriving place known as a four-season mountain playground. Assorted publications have named Boone one of North America's ultimate outdoor adventure destinations and one of the country's best small towns. Surrounded by hundreds of miles of hiking and biking trails, it is also a hotbed of bluegrass music and home to Appalachian State University. Its lively downtown has enough restaurants to fuel up in style for - and refuel and relax after - a day in the outdoors.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Yiddish Mohicans
description: When the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater decided to revive its 1980's hit "On Second Avenue" this year, casting Mike Burstyn was an easy decision. He speaks Yiddish and knows many of the old songs and routines in the show, a tribute to New York's onetime Yiddish rialto. He ought to: his parents were Pesach Burstein and Lillian Lux, two of the leading lights of that vanished scene. The six-week run at the Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side was enough of a success for Folksbiene to bring the show back for two more months, beginning tomorrow. If Mr. Burstyn's family didn't mark him for a life in the theater, his birthplace did: he grew up at 156 Second Avenue, at 10th Street, the building now anchored by the Second Avenue Deli and bordered by the Yiddish Theater Walk of Fame. (Mother, father and son all have stars.) "I want to support the Folksbiene as much as I can because it's the last of the Mohicans," he said. "It's been in existence for 90 years. It's the only game in town."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, EDNA K.
description: SHAPIRO -- Edna K. The Trustees, Administration, Faculty, Staff, and Alumni of Bank Street College of Education mourn the passing of Dr. Edna K. Shapiro, Distinguished Research Psychologist, Emerita. Dr. Shapiro joined the Research Division at the College in 1951, and served as a lead researcher and faculty member until her retirement in 1986. The author of numerous articles, she continued to be active in projects at Bank Street after her retirement. She co-edited, with faculty member Nancy Nager, a book on the history of progressive education and its evolution over time. "Revisiting a Progressive Pedagogy: The Developmental-Interaction Approach" was published by SUNY Press in 2000. Edna is greatly missed at Bank Street, and the entire College community extends its deeply felt condolences to her sons Saul and Daniel and to their families. A memorial honoring Edna and her work will be held at Bank Street on November 11, at 4 P.M.

title: Arts, Briefly; 2 Columbus Circle Is Sold

Alterations to the building are to begin immediately, and the museum plans to occupy it by early 2008. The closing ends a three-year struggle in which preservationists fought to prevent changes to the 1964 building, right, designed by Edward Durell Stone. Its Venetian-inspired marble-clad facade and lollipop-like columns are viewed by Stone's defenders as a turning point in Modernist design. Its facade and interior spaces will be revamped under a design by Brad Cloepfil of Allied Works Architecture, which is collaborating with Gary Edward Handel & Associates. The building has been unoccupied since 1998. The museum also announced that it had raised more than $48 million in a capital campaign started three years ago. The fund-raising goal has increased to $65 million from $50 million to support enhancements to the design and endowment, the museum said.

'Wanda'
description: All hail Isabelle Huppert. There are already a multitude of reasons to celebrate this great French actress, and here is another: thanks to her, one of the classics of 1970's American cinema has begun to resurface after decades of neglect. In 1969, the actress Barbara Loden, then married to Elia Kazan, directed a modestly scaled drama called "Wanda" from her own original screenplay. Shot in 16 millimeter and blown up to 35, the film pivots on the title character, an unmoored loner from Pennsylvania coal country, beautifully played by Loden (above) herself, who drifts through life and men like flotsam. Working under the sign of Cassavetes, Loden counted Godard and Warhol among her influences, though in one interview stated she did not belong to any new wave: "It's the old wave. That's what they used to do. They took a camera and they went out and shot. Around that act this whole fantastic apparatus grew up -- the Hollywood albatross. They made a ship out of lead. It won't float any more." Invited to the Venice Film Festival, "Wanda" was justly lauded on its very limited release here. But the brilliant career that should have been was cut short in 1980, when Loden died of cancer at 48. After, "Wanda" seemed to disappear as Loden was written out of the histories of the era: don't bother to look for the film or its maker in the index of "Easy Riders, Raging Bulls," Peter Biskind's seminal book about 1970's American cinema; they aren't there. Happily, Ms. Huppert's company bought the rights to "Wanda," leading to its release on DVD in France, and on Sunday she will introduce this treasure to a very fortunate audience. (BAMcinmatek, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718)636-4100.)

title: A Filly and a Family, Out to Battle the Odds
description: The movie's official, unwieldy title is "Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story" -- which could mean anything, really. In any case, the story, in its rough outlines, is certainly a familiar one; its themes are the overcoming of past disappointment, reconciliation between parent and child and the triumph of the underdog, which in this case is a horse. Parents who accompany their children to this film, written and directed by John Gatins (whose other writing credits include "Coach Carter"), will find themselves anticipating just about every plot turn, and nodding as each premonition is fulfilled. Nodding through tears, I should add. Yes, "Dreamer" follows a formula, but the formula, when applied with skill and intelligence, as it is here, is pretty much foolproof.

The Listings: Oct. 21 -- Oct. 27; YOUSSOU N'DOUR
description: Last year, the Senegalese singer and bandleader Youssou N'Dour made a political statement with his quietly magisterial album "Egypt" (Nonesuch). Recorded in Egypt with the Egyptian orchestral musician Fathy Salama, its devotional songs provide a glimpse into Islam through the lens of a Senegalese Sufism that emphasizes tolerance. As the second nonclassical artist to be invited to organize a Carnegie Hall Perspectives series, Mr. N'Dour, above, the pioneer of a kinetic style of African rock called mbalax, will use the four-night event to explore aspects of his musical heritage and its effects on the legacy he continues to build. Sunday night's concert, "Night Sky in Sine Saloum," will probe the Senegalese griot tradition with the storyteller Yand Codou Sne and the xalam (lute) player Samba Diabar Samb. On Monday, the "Fresh Face of African Music" show will feature the work of the vocalist Julia Sarr. Mr. N'Dour will be joined on Tuesday by the legendary band he formed a quarter-century ago, the Super toile de Dakar, for a program entitled "The Story of Mbalax," which will revisit musical milestones in the development of this form, which combines griot percussion and spiritual modes with aspects of Afro-Cuban music, American rock and jazz. For Wednesday night's concluding concert, Mr. Salama brings his Cairo Orchestra, with its strings and ouds and oblique flutes, to perform "Egypt," emphasizing both the grandeur and joyous gratitude of Islam. (Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday at 8:30 p.m., Zankel Hall; Wednesday at 8 p.m., Isaac Stern Auditorium, Carnegie Hall; (212)247-7800.)

title: The Listings: Oct. 21 -- Oct. 27; CEDAR LAKE ENSEMBLE
description: It's sheer bravery to create not only another new dance company but also a new studio theater. But Cedar Lake has several things going for it, including the financial support of Nancy Laurie, a Wal-Mart heir. Its participants are known and engagingly individualistic dance figures. The company founder is Benoit-Swan Pouffer, the former Alvin Ailey dancer, and his fellow choreographers in this inaugural program are Edwaard Liang of the New York City Ballet and Jodie Gates, who has danced with the Joffrey Ballet and William Forsythe. The theater is the former Chelsea studio of the photographer Annie Leibovitz, a 16,000-square-foot building with a gabled roof, exposed trusses and presumably some positive artistic karma in the air. Mr. Liang's piece, set to music by Vivaldi, Tan Dun and This Mortal Coil, explores the duality of the past and future. Ms. Gates is contributing a structured improvisation that contemplates the present. And Mr. Pouffer's new "Seed" addresses the cycle of life. He describes the company as a narrative contemporary ballet troupe (the dancer Jessica Coleman-Scott, above), which sounds as if the three choreographers might provide a story or two to grab hold of in their multimedia dances, which are set to live and recorded music. The intermission will be enlivened by music mixed by an onstage D.J. The evening's theme, and the company's mission, Mr. Pouffer says, is replanting and the desire to grow. (Monday through Nov. 12, Cedar Lake Theater, 547 West 26th Street, Chelsea, www.Smarttix.com or (212)868-4444.)

title: Classic Stadiums, Classic Memories
description: NOW that the air has chilled into what they like to call football weather, millions of Midwesterners are following an 80-year tradition, flooding every Saturday into the big university stadiums where their ancestors saw Knute Rockne, Red Grange and Benny Friedman. With professional football just a bunch of ragtag company-sponsored teams in the 1920's, the university squads could barely keep up with their growing fan base. To satisfy the demand, colleges scrambled to erect stadiums that could hold tens of thousands of people, especially in the Midwest. Today's teams could be the original group's great-grandsons, but they are often playing on the same fields.

title: Boone, N.C.
description: THE Appalachian Mountains of North Carolina were America's frontier when Daniel Boone hunted there during his mid-18th century wanderings. Boone would still recognize the beautiful Blue Ridge high country, where in the fall the hills are ablaze with color. But he might be surprised that his namesake town is a thriving place known as a four-season mountain playground. Assorted publications have named Boone one of North America's ultimate outdoor adventure destinations and one of the country's best small towns. Surrounded by hundreds of miles of hiking and biking trails, it is also a hotbed of bluegrass music and home to Appalachian State University. Its lively downtown has enough restaurants to fuel up in style for -- and refuel and relax after -- a day in the outdoors. JEFF SCHLEGEL

Wages in New York City have fallen by 5.5 percent for the lowest third of workers over the past few years, according to the survey, which was conducted by an outside firm and based on telephone interviews with 1,000 low-income families and 500 moderate- and higher-income families. title: Los Angeles Detective and New York Thief Channel 'Pulp Fiction'
description: The opening titles for Shane Black's "Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang" -- based not on Pauline Kael's collection of essays, but rather, at least in part, on a novel by Brett Halliday -- evoke a bygone age of high pop style. The visuals are a loving tribute to the great graphic designer Saul Bass, while the jazzy sounds of John Ottman's score summon up the easy heat of Henry Mancini in his prime. The movie itself, however, evokes a rather different era. I could say that its syncopated editing, its switchback chronology, its fourth-wall-breaking voice-over narration and its hectic mixture of humor and violence represent a fresh and exciting twist on sturdy noir conventions. In fact, I would say just that -- if it were 1995 and I were the kind of person whose mind had just been blown by the cinematic possibilities revealed in "Pulp Fiction."

title: Ruling From the Head, Not the Heart
description: Denver - ONE thing can be said of President Bush's nomination of Harriet Miers. It has focused the spotlight of the Constitution's "advice and consent" clause on its proper target: the nominee's qualifications and not her politics. But one of the most important "qualifications" is a nominee's overarching view of the role of the judiciary in American life. With straight faces, Senate Democrats demand Supreme Court appointees who will "protect individual rights," except, of course, the wrong kinds of individual rights (like the right to be born, the right to bear arms, or the right to be considered for state jobs, contracts or college admission without regard to race or gender). title: The Listings: Oct. 21 -- Oct. 27; 'VII'
description: Photojournalism throws everything that's philosophically complicated about photography into relief. The medium can be used in what are intended as interpretively neutral ways to document life as it is. It can also be a vehicle for political, social and personal statements. In many cases, the lines between objectivity and subjectivity, fact and attitude, are impossible to disentangle. Those lines crisscross like crazy in a group show of work by nine professional photojournalists at the new Hasted-Hunt Gallery in Chelsea. The participants are all part of the collective photographic agency called "VII," formed early in 2001 on the model of the member-run Magnum. As always, it is hard to overlook the paradox that while the purpose of such agencies is to give photographers control over their work, at least some of that work is devoted to recording the lives of people who have lost control of their destinies. Such is the case in John Stanmeyer's picture of drug addicts chained to a post in Indonesia, in images by Ron Haviv and Joachim Ladefoged (above) of uprooted lives in Bosnia and Albania, in Gary Knight's multiple views of a tsunami-ravaged Sumatra, in Antonin Kratochvil's shot of a corpse on a street in Haiti, and in James Nachtwey's close-up of the machete-scarred face of young man in Rwanda. By contrast, Christopher Morris's picture of ardent cellphone conversationalists in Pennsylvania and Lauren Greenfield's images of California teenagers in prom dresses seem to be from an entirely different universe. Yet two pictures by Alexandra Boulat suggest connections: one is of a turbaned man standing outside a ruined house; the other of a young woman in a Western-style formal gown posing in what looks like a hotel. Both were taken in Afghanistan in the last five years. Are the links between the turbaned man, the woman in the gown and the California teenagers confusing? You bet. That's why photojournalism is the art it is. (Hasted Hunt Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212)627-0006, through Dec. 23.)

title: The National Parks Under Siege
description: Year after year, Americans express greater satisfaction with the National Park Service than with almost any other aspect of the federal government. From the point of view of most visitors, there is no incentive to revise the basic management policy that guides park superintendents, a policy that was last revised in 2001 and is usually re-examined only every 10 or 15 years. Longtime park service employees feel much the same way. Yet in the past two months we have seen two proposed revisions. The first, written by Paul Hoffman, a deputy assistant secretary in the Interior Department, was a genuinely scandalous rewriting that would have destroyed the national park system.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Posts 34% Rise in Profit
description: Gazprom, Russia's largest company and the world's largest natural gas supplier, reported a 34 percent rise in net profit for the first quarter. The increase nearly mirrored the 30 percent increase in the price of gas in Gazprom's leading export market, Western Europe, over the same period. Gazprom earned 92.4 billion rubles ($3.2 billion) in the quarter ended March 31. Revenue rose 33 percent, to 339.2 billion rubles ($11.87 billion). The company subsidizes domestic gas prices here from sales to Western Europe; the price in Europe for the quarter was 400 percent higher than the price in Russia, according to the company's earnings report. During the same 9 p.m. slot, "CSI" drew 27.51 million viewers to an episode in which Nick (George Eads) obsessively looked for an abducted girl, having been kidnapped himself in the season finale. The crime show was the most watched of the night by a mile, and led CBS to another Thursday win in all the crucial Nielsen estimates. The one chink in CBS's Thursday armor is that "Without a Trace" does not always rank first among adults 18 to 49. title: Opponents Move to Impeach Malawi President

Members of the president's party walked out of Parliament in protest, saying that the summons violated parliamentary rules and that he would not comply. The president has been in political hot water almost since he took office in May 2004, when he split from his backer and predecessor as president, Bakili Muluzi, and founded his own party. Mr. Mutharika is struggling to deal with Malawi's drought-induced food crisis, which has left as many as four million of its citizens in danger of severe hunger. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: A Brooklyn man was arraigned in Queens criminal court yesterday on charges that he kidnapped and raped a 13-year-old girl as she walked home from school on Tuesday in Woodside. Jofre Bautista, 33, was arrested on Thursday after detectives found the light green minivan he was said to be driving on the day of the assault. The police said they were also investigating whether Mr. Bautista, who the authorities said works in an awning store, was responsible for three other assaults in recent months, all of them involving the touching of young girls on Skillman Avenue in Queens. On Tuesday, prosecutors said, Mr. Bautista called out to the girl from his minivan, then punched her in the face and forced her into the vehicle. When she would not take off her clothes, he raped her at knifepoint, prosecutors said, stole her cellphone, and then let her leave. Mr. Bautista is being held without bail and faces charges including rape, kidnapping, robbery and assault. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

description: Matthew R. Limon had just turned 18 when he had consensual oral sex with a boy just shy of 15 at a Kansas school in 2000. He was convicted of criminal sodomy and sentenced to 17 years in prison. Had the sex been heterosexual, the maximum penalty would have been 15 months.

title: For Mr. Abbas: Time to Act
description: If there's ever been a critical time in the Middle East, this is it. After a tumultuous year that has included the death of Yasir Arafat, the election of Mahmoud Abbas as the new Palestinian leader and the withdrawal of Israeli settlers from Gaza and a handful of West Bank sites, it would be easy for all of the parties involved to push the cruise-control button and drift for a while. Unfortunately, this is a region where the status quo tends to mean carnage, so it is vital that Israelis, Palestinians and all who care about peace in the Middle East take steps to keep the ball rolling.

title: Hard-Living Singer Gives Voice to the Executed
description: Steve Earle turned 50 this year, got married for the seventh time and moved from Nashville to New York City. It was one of two birthday presents to himself (the move, not the marriage). The other is surfing lessons, in Australia, at the end of this month.

title: Russia's Energy Chief Denies Existence of Oil Nationalization Plan
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21 - Russia's top energy official denied Friday that the Kremlin had embarked on a plan to nationalize oil, saying the country was only responding to a global trend toward consolidation in the industry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Recipe For An Evacuation
description: Lemonade powder, yeast and Alfredo sauce were among ingredients in the foul liquid that a former worker doused on the carpet of the Garden City Hotel on Thursday, forcing the evacuation of more than 200 people, the Nassau County police said yesterday. No one was hurt, and the hotel reopened later that night. The suspect, Scott Wallace of Rosedale, was arraigned yesterday in Nassau First District Court in Hempstead on charges of criminal mischief and depositing a false bomb or hazardous substance. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Barrington Moore Jr., 92, Analyst of Totalitarianism, Dies
description: Barrington Moore Jr., a Harvard sociologist whose studies of the contemporary human condition led him to dissect the totalitarian society, particularly as it evolved in the Soviet Union, died last Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 92.

title: The Camaraderie and Strain of Men at Work
description: Luis Lara Malvacas's "Badman" is one of those quiet shows in danger of slipping off the radar on a busy fall weekend. Don't let it. Seen Thursday at Danspace Project, this new work for eight men is beautifully cast, meticulously put together and utterly endearing. Mr. Malvacas cultivates a poetic, mature landscape of male camaraderie that is full of unexpected twists.

Ms. Young's work, however, offers male masturbation, pornographic-movie tableaus, a scene of cocaine consumption and naked women dancing wildly to loud rock music.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 21 - President Hamid Karzai on Friday condemned the reported burning and desecration of two dead Taliban fighters by American troops in southern Afghanistan, and said he had ordered an investigation.

description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly made comments yesterday that appeared to be his most pointed yet regarding the public disagreement earlier this month between city officials and the Department of Homeland Security over a threat to the subway system.

description: Roger Clemens was playing golf with Andy Pettitte in Houston on Thursday when a voice from their past called Clemens's cellphone. It was Joe Torre, wishing the Astros pitchers good luck.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Prosecutors Close Case Against Yushchenko Ally
description: Ukraine dropped a criminal case against a former aide of President Viktor A. Yushchenko a week after Mr. Yushchenko dismissed the prosecutor general who opened it. In a statement, the prosecutor general's office announced that it had closed its investigation against Petro O. Poroshenko, a confectioner and banking tycoon who served as Mr. Yushchenko's national security adviser until last month, when he resigned amid swirling accusations of corruption. The prosecutor who opened the case, Svyatoslav M. Piskun, was dismissed without explanation at the time, but the president's chief of staff, Oleg B. Rybachuk, said yesterday that Mr. Piskun had pursued charges against Mr. Poroshenko for political reasons. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Times Editor Expresses Regrets Over Handling of Leak Case
description: Bill Keller, executive editor of The New York Times, told the newspaper's staff yesterday that he had several regrets over his handling of Judith Miller, the Times reporter who spent 85 days in jail for refusing to testify before a grand jury in the C.I.A. leak case.

title: Rumsfeld and South Korea Defense Chief Agree to Keep Status Quo
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 21 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and his South Korean counterpart on Friday reaffirmed the commitment of both nations to "a solid combined defense posture," and agreed to "accelerate discussions" on whether South Korea should gain command of its military forces in times of war.

title: Different Journeys, but Similar Blueprints
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 - The Houston Astros woke up on the morning of May 25 with a pretty strong sense of where they would finish. It was not the World Series. Teams that average two losses for every three games do not expect to make franchise history.

title: Historians and Scholars Produce New Picture of Witches and WitchHunts, but Questions Remain
description: It is the season of witches -- cute little costumed ones crying "trick or treat" and full-grown adult ones laying claim to Halloween and recounting tales of medieval and early modern persecution.

title: A Young Choreographer's Chance to Shine Among His Stars
description: One rainy day last week, wall-to-wall bodies pirouetted and jetAd across a rehearsal studio at American Ballet Theater's offices in Lower Manhattan, while the choreographer Peter Quanz sat at the front of the room, watching. Suddenly, Mr. Quanz leapt from his chair and with a sharp clap, stopped Veronika Part and Maxim Beloserkovsky in their tracks. He aligned his slight frame - leg extended, hip forward, shoulder back - to demonstrate a position. And then he sat again, still and expressionless.

title: Joy and Pain for 3 Veterans in First Series
description: CHICAGO - THEY have played 6,673 major-league games among the three of them. They are the billboard faces of their teams for the long-suffering fans of Houston and Chicago. But as of this morning, they had never played in a World Series game.

description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 21 - A national movement to have intelligent design taught in science classrooms is "very dangerous," Cornell University's interim president, Hunter R. Rawlings III, said after taking up the issue Friday in a speech. But Mr. Rawlings charged that colleges were not engaging enough in the debate.

title: Dolphins Beat Wilma, but Not Chiefs
description: MIAMI, Oct. 21 - Kansas City Chiefs tight end Jason Dunn said he was a little concerned when he arrived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Friday feeling lethargic after a three-hour flight with his teammates. After all, in less than six hours, the Chiefs were to play the Miami Dolphins.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Kansas: Governor Asks For Minimum Marriage Age
description: In a letter to a state senator, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius called for a minimum marriage age of 16. Ms. Sebelius, a Democrat, asked Senator Stephen Morris, chairman of the legislative coordinating council, to add the issue to an agenda of the special judiciary committee so it could be considered when the Legislature returned in January. The request came three months after the Nebraska attorney general charged 22-year-old Matthew Koso of Falls City, Neb., with statutory rape after his 13-year-old girlfriend got pregnant. The two then married in Kansas with consent of the girl's parents because such a marriage is illegal in Nebraska. Kansas law allows anyone under 18 to marry with parental or judicial consent. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 100 Percent Language Skills Not Necessary For Citizenship
description: Immigrants need not pass a written language test in German to be eligible for citizenship, the federal administrative court in Leipzig said. The ruling was made in a case involving a 42-year-old Turk who has lived in Germany for 27 years and speaks German fluently, but whose application for citizenship was rejected because he had failed German writing tests. title: Reinventing the Mill
description: James Roberts is understandably bitter about the realignment of America's steel industry. "It's hardly fair; hardly right," said Mr. Roberts, a 68-year-old retiree from the Bethlehem Steel plant in Steelton, Pa., who lost his health care coverage and a third of his pension as the company sank into bankruptcy.

title: Senate Pushes Back Debate On Stem Cell Research to '06
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 - A Senate debate over whether to ease federal restrictions on stem cell research will be put off until next year, an influential senator seeking to relax the rules said Friday.

title: Finance Firms Accelerating Their Moves Into China
description: BEIJING, Oct. 20 - After years of hesitancy and half-hearted attempts to break into the Chinese market, American and European financial services companies are investing billions of dollars here in the hopes of reaping huge profits from China's rapid economic rise.

title: U.S. and Europe Move Closer to an Open-Skies Agreement
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 21 - After more than a year of gridlock, the European Union and the United States have moved closer to an agreement on opening their skies to each other, negotiators said Friday.

title: Mixing the Old and the New in a Provocative Way
description: Can Pierre Boulez ever have imagined that four short piano pieces from his steely, rigorously dodecaphonic and anti-establishment "Notations" would be played as an encore during a recital at Carnegie Hall? And who would have thought that this radical early Boulez work would sound so right coming after an exhilarating performance of Schumann's crowd-pleasing "Carnaval"?

description: The crib deaths of 3-month-old twin boys in Brooklyn remained a mystery yesterday, as grief-stricken family members awaited autopsy results.

title: Business Briefs
description: Caterpillar Posts 34% Increase in Earnings But Disappoints Wall Street and Its Shares Fall Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment maker, posted a 34 percent increase in third-quarter profit yesterday but its earnings and its outlook disappointed Wall Street, and its shares fell 10 percent. Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., said strong global demand and price increases helped push its earnings up to $667 million, or 94 cents a share, from $498 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 17 percent, to $8.98 billion from $7.66 billion, a year earlier. The income fell short of the $1.06 a share expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company also cut its full-year forecast, saying it expects 2005 earnings of $3.85 to $4 a share, down from its previous estimate of $4 to $4.20 a share. Caterpillar said it lowered earnings expectations because of a higher tax rate and about $100 million in expected pretax expenses for changes in its dealer distribution software and a product realignment under consideration. Its stock slid $5.11, to $48.92 a share. (AP)

title: Woman of Mass Destruction
description: I've always liked Judy Miller. I have often wondered what Waugh or Thackeray would have made of the Fourth Estate's Becky Sharp.

title: To Louisiana Musicians, Radio City Has Lost Its Allure
description: For struggling musicians of the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra, their season silenced by Hurricane Katrina, it sounded like a spectacular offer indeed: a 10-week job in New York, where they are due anyway for a joint benefit concert on Friday with the New York Philharmonic. At least $1,600 a week. Free transportation and lodging. And a chance to be part of a beloved tradition: to play for the Radio City Christmas Spectacular.

title: Saturday's Top Games
description: No. 10 Texas Tech (6-0) at No. 2 Texas (6-0) 3:30 p.m., ABC (Regional) The Red Raiders have the nation's top scoring offense (53.67 points a game), and quarterback Cody Hodges -- a first-year starter -- leads the nation in total offense (410.8 yards a game). Texas will counter with the nation's third-ranked total defense and quarterback Vince Young, a leading Heisman candidate. Young rushed for 158 yards and 4 touchdowns in last season's 59-20 victory over Texas Tech. The Red Raiders' schedule has been soft, and they needed a late fumble recovery to beat Nebraska in their one real test this season. The Longhorns are heavily favored, but the game could be closer than many think if they make too many turnovers.
