title: U.S. General Sees Further Delay in Iraqi Military Taking Over
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 21 - A top American military commander in Iraq adjusted his forecast for the Iraqi military on Friday, saying it would take from 18 months to two years before it could operate completely on its own.

title: Cutbacks, Bankruptcy and Growing Inflation Signs
description: UNALLOYED good news was in short supply this week. Automakers finally made progress in paring their uncompetitive labor costs, but they still posted huge losses for the last quarter and had little by way of encouragement about their prospects for the future. Sizable layoffs and plant closings are likely early next year, they said, and workers who keep their jobs will have to pay more for their health care.

title: Hughes Falters as Fill-in; Lysacek Takes Second
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21 - With the United States' top two female skaters out with hip injuries, Emily Hughes smelled an opportunity. The 16-year-old Hughes, added to the field of Skate America after Michelle Kwan pulled out, realized she had a chance to crash an international field, to enter the world once enchanted with her sister Sarah and begin the Olympic season with a glimpse of her potential.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The report strongly suggests that the politically motivated assassination could not have taken place without Syrian involvement."

title: Warning, Spying and Hectoring
description: IT'S easy to imagine how busy the comptroller of the United States, David M. Walker, has been since he was appointed in 1998, calling out wayward politicians on fiscal matters.

title: A Few Pitches That Come With Fine Print
description: Everyday we are cajoled with pitches from marketers who have new ways for us to spend money. Most of them just don't make any sense. A few will. Let's take a look at several that keep popping up.

title: Movement With the Passion of Gospel
description: The best of "Sweet Chariots," presented by Clare Byrne Dance on Thursday night at Joyce SoHo, comes with the last piece, "Solo Flight," set to tidal-wave gospel singing by Aretha Franklin, James Cleveland and the Southern California Community Choir. The music seems to flood through Ms. Byrne and set her dancing the joyous physical equivalent of church-service speaking in tongues.

title: They're in the Money
description: The block of 26th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues is an oasis of fine art and even finer footwear, hardly hospitable ground for a dance company. But the Cedar Lake Ensemble, a fledgling contemporary ballet company, possesses one thing most dance companies do not: money.

title: Something Different at Rutgers: Success
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 21 - Ryan Neill is having a hard time getting tickets for his friends and family for Saturday's game at Connecticut. It is the first time Neill, a fifth-year Rutgers senior and a starter at defensive end, has had this problem.

title: Steroids and the Asterisk
description: FARGO, N.D. - EARLY on a chilly afternoon in these weeks before the Christmas rush, there are few enough customers in the West Acres Shopping Center, an enclosed mall constructed in the 1970's, that the sounds of heels clicking against the floors of the bright and clean corridors echo from storefront to storefront.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Indonesians' suspicions that the United States is not treating them as equals in the fight against terrorism misstated the nationality of the people who died in greatest numbers in the Bali bombings of 2002. They were Australians; 88 of them perished. The toll for Indonesians at that time was 38.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Is Shot To Death
description: A 46-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot while walking in Ozone Park shortly before 3:30 p.m. yesterday, the police and witnesses said. The victim, whose name was not released pending notification of his family, was walking on 112th Street between Rockaway Boulevard and 111th Avenue when a young man in a blue hooded sweatshirt ran up behind him and shot him three times in the chest, witnesses said. He was transported to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead at 4 p.m. The gunman's picture, captured by surveillance cameras, was being shown to witnesses by investigators. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,974 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: A Lifetime in Recovery From the Cultural Revolution
description: SHANGHAI - SOMETIMES a single life can tell more about a country's experience than a shelfful of history books. Many Chinese people of a certain age have such lives -- rich in struggle, in suffering, in the consequences of man's folly, but often enough, too, in a measure of redemption.

title: Croyle Is Finally Fulfilling His Promise at Alabama
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 21 - To understand how Alabama (6-0) is ranked fifth in the country, it helps to stop in among the cedars and loblolly pines of North Alabama, at a place where wayward parents drop off their children with no intention of coming back to get them, and where tales of neglect are as plentiful as field larks. That place is the Big Oak Ranch, an orphanage for boys.

title: Lottery to Be Used for Openings in Top Upper West Side Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has approved the use of a lottery system to allocate hundreds of empty seats in some of the highest-performing neighborhood schools on the Upper West Side, the city's Department of Education said yesterday.

title: Knicks Pair Return to Site of Missed Opportunity
description: DALLAS, Oct. 21 - Over the course of eight weeks last spring, Malik Rose was robbed of three championship rings, and Larry Brown had one practically ripped from his finger. The scene of this virtual crime spree was San Antonio, so there will be awkward feelings for both men when the Knicks travel there Saturday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Detective Charged With Drunken Driving
description: A city detective was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated, and his partner was suspended, after a Chinatown resident called 911 about them early yesterday morning, the police said. They said the resident observed Detective Michael Grady, 40, urinating against a building near 150 Baxter Street shortly after 2:30 a.m., while Detective Donald Herlihy, 42, stood nearby. The license plate number on the detectives' vehicle was traced, leading to the arrest of Mr. Herlihy, an 11-year veteran, and the suspension of Mr. Grady, a 13-year veteran, the police said. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTH, RONA

Ruth Teitelbaum, Laurence Roth, Amy, David, Meg, Sofia & Tyler Roth, Carl, Jessica, Ezra & Jonah Teitelbaum

title: Strong Winds and Rain Whip the East Coast of Yucatn
description: CANCN, Mexico, Oct. 21 - Hurricane Wilma slammed into the Yucatn coast with howling fury Friday, flooding streets, downing trees and power lines and stranding thousands of tourists and residents in crowded shelters.

title: A Dance Suite, a Requiem, More Than a Hint of Russian
description: Intentionally or not, Russia has long been exporting musical talent around the globe, but since the collapse of the Soviet Union, it has stepped up its importing as well. In 1997 the young Milanese conductor Gianandrea Noseda was named principal guest conductor of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, becoming the first foreigner to occupy that post. With the theater's packed schedule and its hyperkinetic boss, Valery Gergiev, the Mariinksy cannot have been a placid place to cut one's teeth. No wonder there is a whirling excitement to Mr. Noseda's gestures on the podium, at least as witnessed on Thursday night, when he returned to lead the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. If only more of it translated into the music.

title: Reinsdorf's Little Secret: Even Enemies Like Him
description: CHICAGO - BORN and raised in Brooklyn, he has called himself "the luckiest Jew alive," but he officiates at weddings as an ordained minister of the Universal Life Church. He has led owners in attempts to drive a stake into the heart of the union, but there are player agents who swear love and devotion to him. He led the movement that ousted Fay Vincent as commissioner in 1992, but even Vincent speaks highly of him.

title: Famous Allies of Forrester and Corzine Head to New Jersey to Praise Them to Voters
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hopped across the Hudson River yesterday to raise money for New Jersey Democrats and give a warm endorsement to a Senate colleague, Jon Corzine, in the race for governor.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Demolition Hearing Is Disputed
description: Community Board 1 has withdrawn in protest as co-sponsor of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's information session on Monday on the impending demolition of the contaminated former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street. Julie Menin, the board chairwoman, said the format, in which residents' questions are to be answered individually at small tables, deprived the public of a forum "where concerns are relayed and everyone can hear them." Representative Jerrold L. Nadler criticized the format as "inherently undemocratic and profoundly counterproductive." In response, Michael Haberman, a vice president of the corporation, said the format would be amended so "questions asked at the tables will be noted and we will reconvene for a group discussion regarding frequently asked questions." David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Shirley Horn, Jazz Singer and Pianist, Is Dead at 71
description: Shirley Horn, a jazz singer and pianist who drew audiences close with a powerfully confidential, vibratoless delivery, died yesterday at a nursing home in Cheverly, Md. She was 71. Her death was announced by Regina Joskow, vice president of publicity at the Verve Music Group, Ms. Horn's label.

title: A Composer's Work Becomes a Platform for Political Ideals
description: Frederic Rzewski's piece "The People United Will Never Be Defeated!" and "Bring Them Home!" are separated by 24 years, but the titles share exclamation points. The two works were part of the Composer Portraits series at the Miller Theater on Thursday and they let us know some of the things still on the mind of this 67-year-old American composer and some ways he has moved on.

title: Foul Play Ruled Out in Death of Baby at Agency's Office, but Cause Is Still Unknown
description: A day after a month-old baby boy stopped breathing at a Newark office of New Jersey's child welfare agency, investigators said yesterday that they had ruled out foul play, but were no closer to determining what had caused his death.

title: Unending Housing Boom Tosses Aside Rate Increases and the Old Rules
description: THE housing boom in the United States has survived 11 rate increases by the Federal Reserve. Lately it has faced jawboning from Fed officials who warn bankers not to ease lending standards too far and caution homeowners that, as one Fed governor, Donald L. Kohn, said this week, "a substantial slowing in the pace of house-price appreciation seems inevitable."

title: Fire in a Greenwich Village Station Snarls Morning Rush

title: Leak Prosecutor Is Called Exacting and Apolitical

Fitzgerald earned a public reputation for meticulous preparation, a flawless memory and an easy eloquence. Only his colleagues knew that these orderly achievements emerged from the near-total anarchy of his office, where the relentless Mr. Fitzgerald often slept during big cases.

Their radio station, La Mega (97.9 WSKQ-FM), is No. 2 in New York, the top radio market in the country. title: Acting Out a Song's Narrative With a Full Physical Presence
description: I had heard Christopher Maltman on CD and been pleased with his beautiful baritone, at once creamy and strong, and his command of his texts. I had heard of him through reports of his fine performance in his Metropolitan Opera debut in September in "Ariadne auf Naxos." I knew he had won the Lieder Prize at the prestigious Cardiff competition in 1997 and is accounted a song specialist. But I was disappointed by my first live hearing of him in a program of French and German songs at Zankel Hall on Thursday night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire At Macy's Closes Two Floors
description: The seventh and eighth floors of Macy's flagship store in Herald Square were evacuated about 4:30 p.m. yesterday after a clothing rack caught fire in the children's department on the seventh floor, a store spokeswoman, Elina Kazan, said. No one was hurt, and the cause of the fire was under investigation, Ms. Kazan said. The fire caused little damage, she said, and the eighth floor was reopened about 7 p.m. The seventh floor remained closed last night. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Archdiocese Promises Accounting
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston promised to disclose its finances fully to the public, including an accounting of money used to settle claims of sexual abuse by members of the clergy. Starting next year, the archdiocese will release consolidated audit reports for the fiscal years 2004 and 2005 and will continue to do so annually. Later in 2006 the archdiocese will publish a complete account of its finances and will release a "full accounting" of sexual abuse payments, according to a letter Archbishop Sean P. O'Malley sent to parishioners this week. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Mother Of Dead Children Files Plea
description: A 23-year-old woman charged with killing her three children by throwing them into San Francisco Bay on Wednesday pleaded not guilty. The woman, Lashuan T. Harris, of Oakland, whose name has been spelled different ways in public documents, suffered from schizophrenia, her family has said. She was held without bail at San Francisco General Hospital, said her lawyer, Teresa Caffese. Ms. Caffese, a public defender, said Ms. Harris was undergoing psychiatric evaluations. Ms. Harris is charged with three counts of murder, three counts of assault and issued special circumstances, a legal designation that allows for the death penalty. The family has said Ms. Harris told relatives that voices in her head instructed her to kill the children by feeding them to the sharks. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: Big in Japan, but Mostly a Duck Here
description: In Japan, Aflac is a major supplier of health and life insurance, covering one in every four people. This market accounts for 70 percent of Aflac's operating earnings. In the United States, Aflac is a duck. Despite its 50-year history as a provider of supplemental health and life insurance, Aflac barely registered with Americans until they heard the word squawked by a duck voiced by the comic Gilbert Gottfried in commercials that began running in 2000.

title: Debunking the Myths of Budgeting

Even phrases like "I can't, I'm on a budget" or "I'm tightening my belt" have overtones of deprivation and dry toast.

Following are some of the best places to sin while you can.

title: 'A Thousand Years of Good Prayer': Double Agent
description: Yiyun Li was born in Beijing and moved to the United States in 1996, and in her accomplished first story collection she offers a subtle and original perspective on the latest chapter in China's turbulent history: its recent transformation from an inefficient Marxist dictatorship into one of the world's fastest growing economies. Many of the stories in "A Thousand Years of Good Prayers" are set in the 1990's, and Li is a valuable firsthand guide to this decade of mind-bending change. These narratives are about shifts and adjustments: parents make allowances for their children (and vice versa), and all her characters have to decide how to cope with the past - both personal and political - in order to stand a chance in an uncertain future. Li's ability to write about both her native and adoptive countries - her characters include Chinese immigrants in America and migrs on return visits to China - makes her a skillful double agent. The cross-cultural dispatches she delivers require rapid adjustments on the part of the reader, too.

title: Vieques: Treasuring an Island's Rough Edges
description: A YEAR ago, Vieques was at a crossroads: Left turn, it would have been on its way to becoming a bit like Key West before the trinket shops and theme bars eclipsed its bohemian allure. Right turn, it would have headed in the direction of St. Bart's - a tropical playground where the painfully chic take their Herms towels and their diamond watches to the beach.

title: In Chilling U.N. Assassination Report, Fake Assassin and Intricate Plot by Top Syrians
description: By the summer of 2004, Syrian officials, long accustomed to running neighboring Lebanon, were fed up with its prime minister, Rafik Hariri. So, a United Nations investigation found, they decided to kill him.

title: America's Aquarium, Seen From the Inside
description: A WHITE iron gate with missing letters that once spelled a famous name is the only indication that the father of the atomic bomb, J. Robert Oppenheimer, made this place his retreat. Down a steep concrete driveway off North Shore Road on St. John lies the house where the scientist vacationed for about 10 years starting in the late 1950's. He left it to his daughter, who willed it to the island, and it is now painted a vivid ocher and sometimes used as a community center. In front of the house, palm trees and sea grapes incline gently over a narrow, curved expanse of white sand called Gibney Beach.

title: Dancing With the Devils in the Dominican Republic
description: A SMALL, pothole-laden city in the central valley of the Dominican Republic, anchored by a concrete-pillared, irregularly shaped cathedral whose decidedly ugly look takes some time to grow on you, La Vega isn't high on the to-do list of most travelers. There are no beaches, a few tolerable hotels, some unremarkable restaurants and, for 11 months of the year, no real reason to go there.

title: Guys
description: Remember when women were called girls (On Language, William Safire, Oct. 9)? Remember when the women's movement cried, "Hey, call us women!"? But few people seemed able to wrap their lips around that word. Then we became guys. Everyone felt cool calling women guys. Like the waiter who asks, "Are you guys ready to order?" when it's just my friend Eva and me. But "folks," "people" and "everybody" are strong, useful words. And "Hi, are you ready to order?" leaves out gender without being impolite.

description: KOGEN--Rabbi David C. The Joint Retirement Board for Conservative Judaism notes with profound sorrow the passing of Rabbi David C. Kogen, a trustee since 1959. He headed the Nominations Committee for many years, served as Board Chairperson in 1989 and 1990, and was instrumental in arranging a high quality retirement savings plan for rabbis, cantors, executive directors, educators and support staff of synagogues and agencies of Conservative Judaism. Rabbi Kogen will be greatly missed but his memory will be a blessing. Our condolences are extended to Dena, his devoted wife of 58 years, and his children. Rabbi Matthew H. Paid Notice: Deaths   MOONEY, ROBERT KNAPP
description: MOONEY--Robert Knapp. Former Vice Chairman of Allied Van Lines and Chairman of Hartford Despatch, has died. He was 85. A lifelong resident of Connecticut until his retirement, Mr. Mooney was chosen as the state's Small Businessman of the Year in 1987. Son of Edward G. and Grace K. Mooney, he succeeded his father in the family's moving and warehousing business. A graduate of Harvard University and the Harvard School of Business Administration, Mr. Mooney served with the Chinese First National Army in WWII for which he received the Bronze Star and China's Order of the Flying Cloud. Devoted to the city of Hartford, he was chairman of the Chamber of Commerce and a Regent of the University of Hartford. He served as director of the Hartford Institute for Criminal and Social Justice and the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving. He was a Trustee of the Wadsworth Atheneum and the New Britain Museum of American Art. He leaves his wife, Barbara Connell Mooney; five children, E. Chadwick Mooney of Rancho Santa Fe, CA; Christopher G. Mooney of Larchmont, NY; Francia K. Mooney of Jamestown, NC; Cameron H. Mooney of Redding, CA; Anson B. Mooney of West Hartford, CT; two sisters, Mrs. John Kelly of Wayland, MA and Mrs. Thomas Sutton of Duxbury, MA; and six grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the "Robert Knapp Mooney Memorial Fund", payable to the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, 600 Main St., Hartford, CT 06103. A memorial service will be held at 10 am, Saturday, November 5, 2005, at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford. In Florida, a service will be held at 11am, Saturday, February 18, 2006, at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Boca Grande. Funeral services were private.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Oct. 23-Oct. 29; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: There's something nice about a concerted effort to get a neglected work back on the map. People are starting to figure out that a premiere alone is not enough to get attention: it takes co-productions between companies, repeated performances, recordings. So RICHARD RODNEY BENNETT's opera "THE MINES OF SULPHUR," written in 1965, continues to resurface on our radar: first at Glimmerglass last summer, then as a recording of that performance, and now at City Opera, where the same production is opening today and will be performed five times (through Nov. 5). Today at 1:30 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday nights at 7:30, New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500; $16 to $120.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REAVIS, THETIS TOULIATOU
description: REAVIS--Thetis Touliatou, of New York and Stonington, CT, unexpectedly on October 14, 2005. Adoring of and adored by her daughter and son-in-law, Helen D. ("Heidi") Reavis, and Steven Engel, and loving of and loved by her sister and brother-in-law, Diana and Roy Vagelos, her nieces and nephews, Ellen Masseur, Andrew Vagelos, Cynthia Roberts, Randall Vagelos and their families, her niece and nephews, Cate Reavis, David Reavis, Jamie Reavis and their families, as well as the Andris family, the Copsinis family, the Eitel family, the Engel family, the Harocopos family, the Touliatos family, and numerous other close relatives, friends and colleagues. A graduate of Smith College (Phi Beta Kappa) and The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, Thetis spent her career in foreign policy and education and for 24 years worked at The Foreign Policy Association, most recently as its Vice President, Public Affairs. She was actively involved with many organizations including The Women's City Club of New York, UNIFEM (United Nations Development Fund for Women) and The Smith College Club of New York City. Thetis is already sorely missed. No one who knew Thetis was left untouched by her generosity, love, friendship, kindness and intelligence. A family service will be held in Stonington, Connecticut. A memorial service to honor Thetis will be held in NYC later this year. At that time, the family will communicate with respect to contributions in lieu of flowers.

title: Non Amour
description: A Frenchman named Jacques introduced himself late one evening as I exited the F train at Bergen Street, near my Brooklyn apartment. He said he'd seen me reading on the train and hoped I would stop and talk for a couple of minutes. I was flattered. How could I not be? Here was a guy who actually thought I'd been reading and not staring vacantly at a page while the lyrics to Gwen Stefani's "Hollaback Girl" ran through my head. I liked him for that. We walked out of the station, and as the last passengers from the train disappeared, Jacques asked me where I was from. Not unusual. Strangers have asked me where I'm from since I was a little kid. I don't look all-American -- or even all-anything-else. In first grade, I broke a boy's heart when I confessed that I wasn't a Seminole, I was just Jewish. Ten years later, the same thing happened with a girl who did missionary work and thought I was part Vietnamese. I don't know why I feel obligated to disappoint these people with the truth. When an old man in the Amsterdam airport took my hand and whispered, "Armenian," I could've said, "Yes." And when a guy across the street yelled, "Half-Italian, half-Syrian!" I could've yelled back, "Duh!" But with Jacques, I played it safe. I told him that my grandparents came to America from Russia, which is absolutely true.

But for sheer audacity, no one can surpass the French actress ISABELLE HUPPERT, the focus of a 26-film retrospective at the MUSEUM OF MODERN ART. In recent years Ms. Huppert has run the gamut of challenging roles, playing everything from a repressed, sadomasochistic music instructor in "The Piano Teacher" (for which she won the best actress award at the Cannes Film Festival) to the dissipated and incestuous mother of "Ma Mre," who corrupts her teenage son. It may be impossible to like Ms. Huppert's more extreme characters, but it's equally impossible to dismiss them. She imbues them all with a severity of purpose and an indomitable sense of pride. title: Paperback Row
description: AMERICAN DREAM: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation's Drive to End Welfare, by Jason DeParle. (Penguin, $16.) When the 1996 welfare reform act was passed, DeParle, a reporter for The New York Times who had been writing about social policy for nearly a decade, resolved to "clean my mental slate" and look objectively at the bill's effects. For seven years he followed three African-American single mothers who had spent their adult lives on welfare, describing their battles in the new world of reform. Our reviewer, Anthony Walton, called "American Dream" an "original, courageous and deeply disturbing book that explodes myths of the left as well as the right."

title: Publish and Perish
description: For any writer, the publication of a book, labored over for years, is an exciting event. But excitement is a fleeting emotion, and the business of publicizing the book, so that it sells and the author can earn out his advance, quickly displaces any initial euphoria. The writer then embarks on a tortured journey toward acceptance of the fact, several months after publication, that his book isn't going to vault him into the empyrean of fame, or even improve his life. At the intersection of Elisabeth Kbler-Ross's stages of grief and Stendhal's stages of love, the contemporary author trudges along a predictable path that can only be described, in hindsight, as self-induced misery.

title: St. Thomas
description: WHY GO NOW -- St. Thomas is often too easily dismissed as the Dallas/Fort Worth of the Caribbean -- just a stop on your way to somewhere more glamorous, like St. John or Tortola. And, indeed, the frequency of nonstop flights arriving there from places like New York and Chicago is one reason why this United States Virgin Island is often the default destination for Americans looking for a quick Caribbean getaway once winter arrives. But St. Thomas has a lot more to recommend it than mere convenience. Garishly lush at times, with fat sugary beaches that split its steep green slopes from the surrounding expanse of blue ocean glow, the island also has an authentic urban core, with first-rate restaurants, upscale shops (forget the ones mobbed by day-tripping cruise passengers) and quirky bars lining its historic streets.

title: STEM-CELL BANK CREATED
description: Continuing his effort to make New Jersey a leader in stem cell research, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey announced last Tuesday the creation of what he called the nation's first statewide public bank for umbilical and placental blood to be used by stem cell researchers and patients in need of transplants. Blood from the placenta and umbilical cord contains stem cells, and researchers hope such cells can eventually play a role in curing diabetes, AIDS, multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, as well as in helping patients with strokes or spinal cord injuries. Stem cells can also take the place of bone marrow in transplants for people suffering from leukemia, lymphoma and sickle cell anemia. Use of these cells is less controversial than use of embryonic stem cells, which entail the destruction of an embryo. Currently, less than 1 percent of placental and umbilical blood is donated for research, one expert estimated, and the rest is discarded as medical waste.

description: The dancer SAVION GLOVER has been publicly and seriously interested in jazz for several years; in a run at the Joyce Theater two years ago, he almost maniacally surrendered himself to John Coltrane's arrangement of the song "Nature Boy," with a live band behind him. His new assignment, given to him by Jazz at Lincoln Center, is THELONIOUS MONK. Almost everything Monk wrote had the dance impulse in it: his tunes were springy and full of wit. But their simplicity can be deceptive. (I would love to see Mr. Glover, or any dancer, try the 4/4 over the waltz in Monk's version of "Carolina Moon.") In any case, Monk's work is packed with fresh suggestions for any improvising artist, and "Tappin' Into Monk," Mr. Glover's collaboration with a first-rate quartet--the pianist CYRUS CHESTNUT, the saxophonist TED NASH, the bassist GERALD CANNON and the drummer HERLIN RILEY -- could be one of the best jazz events of the season. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Rose Theater, 60th Street and Broadway, (212)721-6500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHNEIS, H. RICHARD, PH.D., C.P.O.
description: LEHNEIS--H. Richard, Ph.D., C.P.O., 72. Born in Frankfurt, Germany. Died October 15 in NYC. He was founder of Lehneis Orthotics and Prosthetics Associates, Ltd. and was a researcher, teacher, mentor and inventor who held patents on eight devices. Dr. Lehneis was recognized globally for the innovation and evolution of orthoses and prostheses, benefiting his profession and countless patients with limb loss or neuromuscular-skeletal disorders or disease. He was a Consultant and Research Professor of Rehabilitation Medicine at the NYU School of Medicine, and a Fellow of Rusk Without Walls. Dr. Lehneis earned many honors including the prestigious Titus-Ferguson Award, and worldwide acclaim for his humanitarian efforts in Armenia. His contributions have been recognized internationally in over 80 publications. Survived by his wife, Mayumi; his sons, Richard, Alfred and Roger, who continue his work; and his four grandchildren. A Funeral Mass was held October 19 at St. Martin of Tours R.C. Church in Amityville, NY. Donations may be made to the Dept. of Rehabilitation Medicine at NYU School of Medicine, Attn: Mathew Lee, M.D., Chairman, 400 E. 34 St., Suite 600, NY, NY 10016

title: The Catch
description: On a dank, cold morning this past March, full of wind and the gloom of the sub-Antarctic autumn, I stepped off the customs pier in the Falkland Islands port of Stanley and tried to board a pirate ship. The Elqui, a rusted-out heap flying the Guinean flag, sat impounded at the dock, her captain awaiting charges from the British territorial government of South Georgia Island. What had brought the Elqui and its 30-odd Indonesian, African and South American crew members to this remote harbor at the bottom of the world were Chilean sea bass, 13 tons of which now lay frozen below the ship's deck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHILLIPS, ROBERT
description: PHILLIPS - Robert. Passed away at age 83, after a brief illness, in Florida, on October 21, 2005. He is survived by Eleanor, his wife of 55 years, his daughter Randi and her husband Robert Krieger, his son Steven and his wife Wendy, and his granddaughters, Rebecca and Elizabeth. He adored them all without limit, just as they adored him. Robbie, as he was always known, grew up in The Bronx and remained a quintessential New Yorker even after moving to Palm Beach more than 10 years ago. He founded Warbern Plastics, a manufacturer of hangers and an innovator in the shipment and display of garments. He also maintained vigorous commitments to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and to the Chemotherapy Foundation, which he served eight years as President. Passionate about business, passionate about the fullest and most energetic appreciation of life, and passionate about people who shared his enthusiasm, he was a devoted husband, a loving and inspiring father, and a tireless friend. He will be profoundly missed. Service will be held on Monday, 11:15 am, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made to the Chemotherapy Foundtion, 183 Madison Ave, NYC 10013.

title: Up Front
description: JOHN SIMON, whose review of new books about Shakespeare by Peter Ackroyd and James Shapiro begins on Page 8, has long believed that the finest Shakespearean productions "make no facile concessions to the audience"; the best American Shakespeare he's ever seen, he said in an interview, was Jack O'Brien's "Henry IV" at Lincoln Center in 2003, which was "free from gimmickry and patronization." But he also thinks "American actors are not properly trained to deal with poetry, partly through their own fault, because they don't see much profit in bothering with it. How much classical theater is there around? Moreover, unlike British English, which has a melody to it, American English is flat and has no music. Still, great actors, a rare breed, can compensate."

title: The Budget Isn't Broken

To this end, they have placed an initiative, known as Proposal 1, on the state ballot. This amendment would give greater budgetary authority to the Legislature, fundamentally altering the current budget process. It is one of the most sweeping and significant constitutional changes to be proposed in New York since the constitutional convention of 1967.

Location Doubt
description: LAST SPRING, without much investigation or dispute, my husband and I decided that we would be married at the United Nations. This choice of location, I would learn much later, aroused curiosity among those who didn't know me well. Rumors started circulating that I was marrying a diplomat or someone otherwise glamorously connected to the international community. This was not my destiny. My husband is an English professor whose window of available dates was inflexibly arranged around the University of Alabama's football schedule, possible postseason bowl games, his fantasy-baseball commitments and the grand slam tournaments of the P.G.A. Location research was largely my territory. Rummaging through a recycling bin at work, I unearthed a copy of a magazine for event planners and discovered that any regular civilian could be married at the U.N. -- even someone who didn't know if Burkina Faso was the name of a country or the name of a person who may or may not have won the Booker Prize.

title: Inside the List
description: MAKING HIS CASE: Michael Connelly, taking a break from his Harry Bosch detective novel series, has the new No. 1 book on the hardcover fiction list. "The Lincoln Lawyer" is his first legal thriller, and its sales have been pushed by some of the strongest reviews of his career. (Writing in the Book Review two weeks ago, Marilyn Stasio called the novel "a powerhouse drama fueled by cynicism and driven by a criminal defense lawyer . . . who works for the scum of the earth and makes no apologies.") On the nonfiction side, the highest ranking new entry is Joan Didion's memoir "The Year of Magical Thinking." It's Didion's eighth book to make The Times's fiction or nonfiction list in hardcover. Her first two books, the novel "Run River" (1963) and the essay collection "Slouching Towards Bethlehem" (1968) did not appear here, and neither did her two most recent books, the essay collection "Political Fictions" and the family history "Where I Was From." But in between, almost everything she has published -- with the exception of "Miami" (1987) -- has made the hardcover lists. Didion's most popular books, in terms of this page, appeared in the late 1970's and early 80's. Her novel "A Book of Common Prayer" had a 15-week run in the spring and summer of 1977; her essay collection "The White Album" hung on for 13 weeks in the summer and fall of 1979; and "Salvador" spent 8 weeks on the nonfiction list in the spring of 1983.

title: Another Woman
description: Diane Keaton, who the critic Pauline Kael once suggested "may be a star without vanity," is fretting about her makeup. Keaton sits on an elevated director's chair in front of a large mirror in a bare dressing room, worrying that an indiscernible powdery dab on her nose will show up on camera -- she's about to shoot a public-service announcement on behalf of the dogs and cats left homeless in the wake of Hurricane Katrina -- if she doesn't locate some putty-colored foundation to cover it. The actress, who will turn 60 in January, returns to the screen in December in "The Family Stone," an ensemble drama in which she plays the dying but buoyant matriarch of a large and strenuously colorful brood. Keaton is deeply attractive in a way that you don't see much in Hollywood anymore (or on the Upper East Side or in any upscale area, for that matter): she looks, that is, the way a woman her age might look if pre-emptive cosmetic surgery for actresses over the age of 30 hadn't somehow become the law of the land. Keaton's slightly Nordic-looking features and good bones are still very much in evidence, but if you peer closely you can see a faint tracing of lines etched around her unplumped-up mouth and at the corners of her slanted, blazingly alert hazel eyes.

Gas Taxes: Lesser Evil, Greater Good
description: There's no serious disagreement that two major crises of our time are terrorism and global warming. And there's no disputing that America's oil consumption fosters both. Oil profits that flow to Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern countries finance both terrorist acts and the spread of dangerously fanatical forms of Islam. The burning of fossil fuels creates greenhouse emissions that provoke climate change. All the while, oil dependency increases the likelihood of further military entanglements, and threatens the economy with inflation, high interest rates and risky foreign indebtedness. Until now, the government has failed to connect our crises and our consumption in a coherent way. That dereliction of duty has led to policies that are counterproductive, such as tax incentives to buy gas guzzlers and an overemphasis on increasing domestic oil supply, although even all-out drilling would not be enough to slake our oil thirst and would require a reversal of longstanding environmental protections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAW, IRVING F.
description: SHAW--Irving F. On October 22, 2005. Adoring and devoted husband of Pauline for almost 67 years. Beloved father of Rochelle Slovin and Martin Shaw, loving brother of Ruth Newman, Sylvia Small and Leon Schertzer, fond grandfather of Karl Slovin, Eric Slovin, Adam Shaw and Kayla Shaw, delighted great-grandfather of Charlotte Slovin and Benjamin Slovin. Co-inventor of a number of pharmaceutical patents, he was a contributor to the National Formulary and assisted in the editing of the U.S. Pharmacopoeia. For 30 years he served as President of the pharmaceutical manufacturing firm, Vitarine Co., Inc. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Parenteral Drug Association and the National Association of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers. Upon the acquisition in 1960 of Vitarine by West Chemical Products, he was named a member of of the Board of Directors of West Chemical. A leader in his community, he was President of Congregation Etz Chaim (the Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Center) and a Director on the Board of the Metropolitan Region of the United Synagogue. He was elected Mayor of the Village of East Rockaway, New York, for two terms, and served as the President of the Nassau County Village Officials Association. His professional integrity, civic service, and lifelong commitment to charity serve as a model for his family, friends, associates and employees. Services today, 11:30 am, Congregation Etz Chaim, 295 Main St., East Rockaway. Contributions may be made to the Irving F. Shaw and Pauline K. Shaw Chemistry Scholarship Fund at Brooklyn College.

It makes sense to give it a try, while watching carefully to make sure some of the poorest and most vulnerable people in the country do not suffer as guinea pigs.

"Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story" (DreamWorks), a family film about a horse trainer and his daughter starring Kurt Russell and Dakota Fanning, opened at No. 2 with $9.3 million. "Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit" (DreamWorks) is at No. 3 in its third week of release with $8.7 million, bringing its cumulative sales to $44.1 million. Last week's No. 1, "The Fog" (Sony), a remake of the 1980 cult horror film, was at No. 4 with $7.3 million, for total sales of $21.5 million. "North Country" (Warner Brothers), a fictionalized account of a Minnesota iron miner who prevails in the country's first sexual-harassment class-action lawsuit, opened at No. 5 with $6.4 million. He was born and raised in Long Beach, NY where he practiced medicine for more than forty years and served as the Director of the Department of Family Practice from 1977 to 1982 at Long Beach Memorial Hospital. He was a graduate of George Washington University and the University of Maryland, and was a veteran of WW II, where he served as a Major in the U.S. Army Medical Corps. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife, Barbara and is survived by his two sons, Andy and Jeff: his daughtersin-law Michele and Lori; and three grandchildren, Marli, Alex, and Jessica. As a physician, he was revered and sought after for his knowledge, compassion and thoughtfulness. As a father, he was loving and caring and willing to do anything for his children. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Australians Offer to Buy Copenhagen Airports
description: Macquarie Airports, the world's No.2 airport operator, offered to buy Copenhagen Airports, valuing the airfield owner at about 15.7 billion kroner ($2.5 billion) as the Australian company accelerates expansion in Europe. Macquarie, based in Sydney, already holds 14.7 percent of the Danish operator, and is offering 2,000 kroner ($320) a share, or 31 percent above the average price on Oct. 21, Macquarie's chief executive, Kerrie Mather, said at a news conference in Copenhagen. Macquarie owns stakes in airfields in Brussels, Rome and Sydney and in Birmingham and Bristol, England. The board of Copenhagen Airports is recommending the offer. The Danish government, however, said it would not sell its 39.2 percent stake in the company. Finance Minister Thor Pedersen said in a statement, "The government intends to continue to be a joint owner to ensure that Copenhagen Airports in future will also be run so that it covers the needs of the community that is associated with Denmark's central airport."

The last segment of the line, through a tunnel under the Palisades to stations in Union City and North Bergen, is scheduled to open in January. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Top Energy Official Resigns Abruptly
description: Timur Kulibayev -- considered the second-most-powerful person in Kazakhstan after his father-in-law, President Nursultan Nazarbayev -- has resigned as first vice president of the state oil company, the post he used to set energy policy in the oil-rich Central Asian country, the government news agency reported over the weekend. Mr. Kulibayev has been in senior positions at the state oil company, now called KazMunaiGaz, since 1997. The company produces about a fifth of Kazakhstan's output of 1.1 million barrels a day, owns the state pipeline grid and is the industry regulator. The unexpected resignation came at a time of frantic deal-making between KazMunaiGaz, CNPC International of China and Lukoil of Russia over the disposition of Kazakhstan's top two independent oil companies.

description: TRANS-ATLANTIC BUSINESS BARGAINS -- Competition over the North Atlantic is really heating up, as domestic airlines toss more capacity into the routes and all-business-class start-ups like Eos and MAXjet schedule daily flights between New York and London. Two weeks ago, British Airways, whose new chief executive, Willie Walsh, slashed trans-Atlantic business-class fares when he ran Aer Lingus, announced a 20 percent sale on business-class fares with a seven-day advance purchase. British Air also announced a promotion for members of its Executive Club frequent-flier program: through Dec. 31, a round-trip trans-Atlantic ticket in Club World business class or in first class gets you a total of 50,000 miles, counting a bonus of 40,500 miles. Meanwhile, MAXjet, which will fly the trans-Atlantic route using Boeing 767 aircraft configured only with 102 seats, announced its second fare sale, even before it was scheduled to begin flying next Tuesday. MAXJet's new round-trip introductory fares are $1,493 including fees and taxes, marked down from the the $1,708 announced in late September.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Fox's Party Picks Candidate

Mr. Caldern will face the popular former mayor of Mexico City, Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, of the Democratic Revolution Party. A third party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which held the presidency for 71 years until Mr. Fox's victory in 2000, is to choose its candidate next month. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Sex and Surgery Trump Sox and Politics
description: The Chicago White Sox and the Houston Astros weren't popular enough to stop the housewives and surgeons on Sunday night. ABC's "Desperate Housewives" (24.86 million) and "Grey's Anatomy" (18.41 million) pulled up the network's prime-time average in Nielsen's estimates, lifting its ratings above Fox's broadcast of Game 2 of the World Series (approximately 15.51 million). ABC has won every Sunday of the fall season so far among all viewers and among adults 18 to 49. A year ago, it was a different story: the Boston Red Sox-St. Louis Cardinals game drew nearly 10 million more viewers than this Sunday's matchup, and Fox carried the night. For NBC, "The West Wing" (7.77 million) continued to have ratings troubles, as its White House leak story line came to a head. (Toby, played by Richard Schiff, did it.) Formerly top-rated, "The West Wing" finished fourth among both total viewers and 18- to 49-year-olds, as did NBC over all on Sunday. CBS was third. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Weight Limits On Bridge Enforced
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority began enforcing a weight limit yesterday on tractor-trailers and other heavy trucks on the Throgs Neck Bridge, which connects the Bronx and Queens. Alarmed by a growing number of tiny cracks in the steel deck structures on either side of the main span, the authority sought to begin enforcing a long-ignored 80,000-pound weight limit on Oct. 1. Trucking companies filed a lawsuit. Late Friday, a State Supreme Court judge allowed the authority, for now, to enforce a 105,000-pound limit and require the trucks to drive in the two center lanes and under 30 miles per hour. The authority is still arguing in court that it has the right to enforce the 80,000-pound limit. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Rejoins Labor Council
description: The New York City Central Labor Council announced yesterday that the city's largest union, 1199/S.E.I.U., had rejoined the labor council, the coordinating body for the city's unions. Brian McLaughlin, the council's president, said that 1199's move would make the council more effective in lobbying City Hall, in political campaigns and in backing unions in labor disputes. Five years ago, 1199, a health care union with 170,000 members in the city, quit the council, partly to save dues money. Its parent, the Service Employees International Union, led a four-union walkout of the national A.F.L.-C.I.O. last summer, but the service employees want to maintain strong local ties with the labor movement. title: Coffins and Buried Remains Set Adrift by Hurricanes Create a Grisly Puzzle
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 24 - The living were not the only ones uprooted by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. The force of the storms literally raised the dead from their resting places in peaceful parish cemeteries, sending nearly a thousand coffins and vaults floating across the Gulf Coast and creating a macabre puzzle for Louisiana coroners and morticians. Storm surges as high as 20 feet transformed two-ton concrete vaults, tombs and coffins into virtual ships that traveled for miles across parish lines, landing in front yards, fields and swamps. One barnacle-encrusted vault found underwater in a marsh is thought to have been a victim of Hurricane Audrey in 1957.

An explosion in March at a BP site near Houston killed 15 people and injured 170, and was followed by two fires and a chemical leak at two of the company's installations. Mr. Baker was treasury secretary under President Ronald Reagan and secretary of state under the first President Bush. BP has been represented by Mr. Baker's law firm in Houston, and it has helped endow a policy institute named for him at Rice University. The law firm said Mr. Baker had not performed work for the company. Mr. Baker said he sold 675 shares of BP upon accepting the assignment, for which he and four other panel members will receive $100,000 each. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Frank Rich Asks Readers, Should the Nobel Prize Embrace New Media?
description: Frank Rich: Harold Pinter is the first playwright to win the Nobel Prize in Literature since Dario Fo in 1997. In my view, hes a worthy recipient  a writer whose vision changed the way we look at the world. (I do not feel this way about Fo, who seemed more a pure political choice on the part of the committee.) But rather than debate Pinters merits, Id like to raise a larger question: In general, theater has been poorly represented throughout the 100-year-plus history of this prize compared to fiction and poetry. Does this say something about the status of theater in international culture since the Nobel began being awarded, at the turn of the 20th century? And if so, is this because of the advent of film and, later, television? Or are there other reasons? Should the great artists in new media  film directors, for instance  be considered for the Nobel in addition to playwrights? (After all, Pinter himself did significant work in film.) Id be curious to hear readers views on these issues, and would like to post the more provocative arguments.

description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice struggled to stay on the high road during a visit to Ottawa, but Canadian leaders and journalists continually brought her back to the issue of American tariffs on Canadian lumber. At the same time, auto manufacturers and dealers are making it much easier for buyers to spend $50,000 in an online transaction, or at least use the Internet to do everything but test-drive the car and drop off the check, industry analysts say.

They bought Smuttynose Pumpkin Ale, baked ghost-shape cookies and savored their favorite sweet, the dark chocolate pumpkin from La Maison du Chocolat. But the pumpkin has competition this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Terrorism Prosecutors Named

Garcia, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced the appointments of two veteran prosecutors, Edward O'Callaghan and David Raskin, yesterday as co-chiefs of the Terrorism and National Security Unit. The federal prosecutor's office has had a long and prominent role in terrorism prosecutions in New York and elsewhere. Mr. Garcia also said that another prosecutor, Robert Buehler, would run a unit that specializes in organized crime, with Richard Daddario as his deputy. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Secretary Accused Of Abusing Time Off
description: A payroll secretary at a Brooklyn school abused her leave time over the last decade, traveling to Trinidad three times while claiming to suffer from work-related injuries, school investigators said yesterday. The secretary, Shirley Walcott, who worked at Public School 91 in Remsen Village, had sole access to computer accounts and records concerning leave time, said Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for schools. Ms. Walcott took many days off after filing dozens of claims over the years citing "line of duty" injuries like a fall in the office, Mr. Condon said. The Department of Education is seeking to fire Ms. Walcott, and her case has been referred to the district attorney. Ms. Walcott's lawyer did not return a call. Susan Saulny (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; Greece Investigates Claims Of Illegal Getty Purchases
description: Greece said yesterday that it was "actively and aggressively pursuing" claims that the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles had illegally acquired ancient Greek artifacts. This allegation of antiquities theft by an American museum is the first since the government began a campaign in 1982 against the British Museum for the return of the Parthenon marbles. Referring to the Getty inquiry, Lazarus Kolonas, Greece's chief custodian of antiquities, said, "We are determined to take all appropriate action against all those proven to be involved in this case, as well as others." The investigation, led by the Greek culture ministry, comes less than a month after the Getty, home to a world-class collection of Roman, Greek and Etruscan works, returned three objects to Italy after claims by local authorities that they were illegally acquired. Greece's accusations center on three artifacts -- a gold wreath, an inscribed tombstone and a marble torso dating to 400 B.C. -- bought by the Getty in 1993, according to local reports. A fourth item, an archaic relief purchased two years later, is also in question. Getty officials have denied any wrongdoing.

He juxtaposes it with modern dance, even using a diagram, while acknowledging the fool's errand of trying to explain a dance that he had earlier called "a device of life itself that dares to live death."

National Briefing | Washington: Democrat Backs White House On C.I.A. Measure
description: A senior Senate Democrat said that Congressional negotiators should to try to accommodate some White House demands to exempt the Central Intelligence Agency from a Senate-approved ban on inhumane treatment of detainees in American custody. "I think something should be worked out," said the senator, Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii. The White House is insisting that the clandestine C.I.A. counterterrorism activities be exempted from a provision of a $445 billion military spending bill by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, that would bar cruel and degrading treatment of prisoners. The Senate approved the measure nearly three weeks ago. Mr. McCain has rejected the White House demand, but Mr. Inouye's comments could weaken his bargaining position in a House-Senate conference that will resolve the issue. Eric Schmitt (NYT)

description: New York City Transit will be able to track vehicles that provide door-to-door rides for disabled people in the Access-a-Ride program under a $16.3 million contract announced yesterday. The contract, with INIT, a German firm with an office in Chesapeake, Va., received preliminary approval yesterday and will go before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board tomorrow. The system will rely on global-positioning satellites to track 1,329 vehicles to improve coordination of trips and the response to breakdowns and delays. The work is for two and a half years and allows for an expansion to another 428 vehicles starting in 2008. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Seeks U.S. Stake
description: Gazprom, the world's largest natural gas producer, signaled its intent yesterday to take a stake in a liquefied natural gas terminal. Alexander Medvedev, the deputy chairman of Gazprom, which is also Russia's largest company, said in an interview that such a venture would provide Gazprom with an outlet in the United States for natural gas from its Shtokman field in the Barents Sea above the Arctic Circle. Mr. Medvedev said Gazprom was discussing the plan with the companies vying to take part in the Arctic project, which include two American concerns, Chevron and ConocoPhillips; two Norwegian companies, Statoil and Norsk Hydro; and Total of France. description: Twenty-six men were arrested on Tuesday night in connection with the destruction of property at a school attached to a synagogue in Williamsburg, the police said. The synagogue, Yetev Lev D'Satmar, has been the focus of a struggle between two brothers over the spiritual leadership of the Satmar Hasidim and control of the congregation's powerful board. The police did not say if the men were Hasidic but did say they were all members of the same religion. The brothers, Aaron Teitelbaum and his younger brother Zalmen, want to succeed their father, the Grand Rabbi Moses Teitelbaum. Investigators said that at 9:30 p.m. on Tuesday, 26 men broke open a door and entered the school, at 152 Rodney Street. Once inside, they destroyed property, breaking cabinets and forcing open lockers and drawers. The men face charges including burglary and criminal mischief, the authorities said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGICH, RONNIE
description: ROGICH--Ronnie, Chestnut55, died in New York City on October 24, 2005 of complications from viral pneumonia. She was born June 10, 1950 in Ione, Washington to Ranny and Ted Rogich. She was raised and spent the majority of her early life in Las Vegas where she attended Valley High School. After graduation, she began her professional dance career in The Folies Bergere Show. Ronnie went on to dance in a variety of other stage productions on the Strip and internationally with headliners Boyce and Hart, Sammy Davis, Jr. and others. Following her dance career, she worked with her brother, Sig Rogich, at R & R Advertising before moving to New York City in 1979. While in New York, Ronnie worked as a legal administrator for 25 years. She had a passion for her family and a love for collecting antiques. Ronnie was preceded in death by her mother, Ranny Rogich (born: Ragnheidur Arnadottir) and her brother, Steve Rogich. She is survived by her husband, Martin Chestnut of New York City and her son Ross Chestnut, currently attending Syracuse University; her father, Ted Rogich; her brother Ed Rogich and his wife Kathy; her brother Sig Rogich and his wife Lori, all of Las Vegas, NV; her brother and sister-in-law, Lt. Colonel Donald and Olivia Davis of Florida, currently stationed in Japan; her nieces and nephew, Britten Rogich of San Francisco, CA, Erin Rogich of Seattle, WA, Olivia Rogich and Sig Rogich, Jr., both of Las Vegas, NV. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM, Saturday, October 29, 2005 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made in Ronnie Rogich's name to the Nathan Adelson Hospice Foundation, 4141 Swenson Street, Las Vegas, NV 89119.

description: Wal-Mart is firing back at Robert Greenwald, the filmmaker whose scathing documentary "Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price" will be released in New York and Los Angeles on Nov. 4 and on DVD on Nov. 15. The company's public relations firm Edelman sent journalists material assailing Mr. Greenwald, including choice snippets from decades-old reviews of his work; it also said that the trailer for his new film was full of inaccuracies. Mr. Greenwald, in an interview, said the company was off base and offered to screen the film for Wal-Mart executives at corporate headquarters in Bentonville, Ark. "I would hope they'd have better use for their stockholders' money," Mr. Greenwald said, than attacking him. Meanwhile, another documentary maker, Ron Galloway of Augusta, Ga., is racing to finish shooting and editing a movie that will praise Wal-Mart, with the company's promotional help but, he said, without any other financial assistance. Mr. Galloway said he was rushing to capitalize on publicity for Mr. Greenwald's movie. He said that his was not the anti-Greenwald film and that Mr. Greenwald's distribution strategy was brilliant. DAVID M.HALBFINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAMES, ABRAHAM
description: SHAMES - Abraham, who built the 1st Industrial Park in the Northeastern US in 195659, died on Sunday October 16, 2005 in Sarasota, Florida. The Westbury Industrial Park, located off Brush Hollow Road on 28 acre tract, bears his name: Shames Drive. He also built and developed the 60 acre, Cardinal Industrial Park, in Hauppauge, just south of the Long Island Expressway during 1966-68. During the 70's he introduced the novel concept of leasepurchase plans, building seven nursing homes and health related facilities on Long Island and Upstate New York. In 1977 he converted the old Roosevelt Raceway Movie Cinema on Old Country Road to Health 'N Sports Racquetball Club & Spa. During 1985 he redirected his life and moved to Longboat Key Florida. Mr. Shames was very active with Long Island and Sarasota philanthropic and civic organizations. On Long Island he had served as the President of the Mental Health Association of Nassau County; Board Member of St. Francis Hospital (Roslyn); President of the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation; Master ofthe Masonic, Meadowbrook Lodge (Westbury); Board Member and Humanitarian Award recipient in 1984 of St. Mary's of the Angels Home in Syosset (now MercyFirst) as well as very active in Republican Party politics. He was also involved with Human Resources Center in Albertson, Boy Scouts of America, Nassau County Heart Association, Solomon Schechter Day School, and American Cancer Society. In 1983 he was named the Man of the Year by the Anti Defamation League and in 1986 he had lunch in the Cabinet Room of the White House with President Ronald Reagan. In Florida he was active in the Gift of Life Program, Rotary International; Shriners; served on the Board of the Sarasota Opera and Mote Marine Laboratory in Longboat Key. Mr. Shames was born May 14, 1920 in Brooklyn, New York and served in the US Army during World War II . He died of heart failure 71 days after the love of his life and wife of 62 years, Annette (Harris) died from a brain hemorrhage. He is survived by his sons Jerry (Lakewood Ranch, Florida); Jordan (Great Neck, New York) and Barry (Livermore, California) and daughter, Joy (Westbury, New York) and ten (10) grandchildren.

Composed of more than 500 porcelain blossoms and nearly 100 plaster branches, it covers a 16-by-17-foot ceiling in the dining room of a client's house in Los Angeles. Mr. Wiseman made the blossoms in molds but trimmed them by hand and finished each in one of three glazes (matte, glossy and semigloss), so no two are the same. Gluing the branches in place required clamping each one to the ceiling and holding it there "for a good minute and half," he said. The project was commissioned by the client's interior decorator, Rodman Primack, who added the French chandelier. Mr. Wiseman, 24, said he grew up in Pasadena, Calif., "staring at nature" and uses it as inspiration. He began selling ceramic designs while still a sophomore at the Rhode Island School of Design; after graduating he moved back home and bought a kiln.

description: Like any structures begun over a century ago, the pieces of New York's aging transportation system desperately need updating. Most commuters know this already. When a fire destroyed one 70-year-old signal room in New York City's antique subway, it nearly rerouted thousands of riders for years. People taking trains or buses to work have dealt with regular, sudden breakdowns and disruptions, often explained on intercoms that cannot be understood in any language. Bridges and overpasses across the state also need work, and some highways are so patched and ragged that the only people enjoying the ride are those selling shock absorbers.

title: Kosovo, Still Messy After All These Years
description: Six years and four months after it made Kosovo a ward, the United Nations Security Council has ordered that talks begin on the future status of that blood-soaked Balkan province. This is to give the impression that the outcome is not decided. It is, and it's independence. The six nations that oversee Kosovo -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Russia -- have ruled out returning it to Serbia, linking it to Albania or partitioning it. So the task of Martti Ahtisaari, the former Finnish president who will lead the talks, is to carve yet another independent state out of the former Yugoslavia.

title: 2,000 Dead, in Context

With the nightly ghoulish news of improvised explosives and suicide bombers, Americans perhaps do not appreciate that the toppling of Saddam Hussein and the effort to establish a democratic government in Iraq have been accomplished at relatively moderate cost -- two-thirds of the civilian fatalities incurred four years ago on the first day of the war against terrorism.

Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUPT, ENID A.
description: HAUPT--Enid A. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center note, with sorrow, the death of Enid A. Haupt, member of the Board of Overseers from 1979 to 1998 and one of the Center's most active and innovative philanthropists for more than half a century. Since 1946, when she made her first gift to Memorial Hospital, Mrs. Haupt's generosity has enabled the realization of many Center efforts. Her contributions were used to develop effective chemotherapy protocols for pediatric leukemia, to augment the building fund from which Memorial Hospital was constructed, and to support the development of the Center's Pediatric Day Hospital. Beginning in 1980, she established a series of endowments to permanently sustain ten Enid A. Haupt Chairs in Radiation Oncology, Cell Biology, Clinical Investigation, Developmental Biology, Hematologic Oncology, Medical Physics, Nursing, Pediatric Oncology, Surgery, and Theraputic Research, enabling us to recruit leading investigators and clinicians to the Center. In 1991, a gift from Mrs. Haupt helped create the Enid A. Haupt Pavilion, an ambulatory care facility on our main campus. Her philanthropy also established the Fresh Flower Program, ensuring the presence of fresh flowers and plants in perpetuity throughout Memorial Sloan - Kettering's patient care and public areas. Mrs. Haupt's visionary altruism, energy, creativity, and friendship will be deeply missed. James D. Robinson III Honorary Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman John R. Gunn Executive Vice President Harold Varmus President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Way Cleared For Meadowlands Plan
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit challenging construction permits for the proposed Xanadu shopping and entertainment center in the Meadowlands yesterday, removing one of the final hurdles facing the $1.3 billion project. The case was filed by Hartz Mountain Industries, an owner of office buildings near the Meadowlands, which lost a bid two years ago for development rights to the proposed site of Xanadu. Hartz Mountain's lawyers argued that a permit allowing eight acres of wetlands to be filled in for the Xanadu project violated federal law and opened the door to a development that would hurt its business by adding traffic congestion to the area. Judge Joel A. Pisano of United States District Court in New Jersey disagreed. "Hartz's business-related injuries," he wrote, "are entirely conjectural."

A mirrored wall reflects a stainless steel counter on a rose-colored glass base, right. The store, Strange Invisible Perfumes, carries a line of prt--porter botanical essences by Alexandra Balahoutis, who devises bespoke blends ($2,100 for a consultation and the first quarter-ounce) in a glass and walnut consulting area, shown at rear. The floor is Douglas fir with a walnut stain. "I wanted a space that was futuristic but with some knowledge of history that was also inviting and feminine," said Ms. Balahoutis, a self-taught perfumer. Her boutique, which opened in early October, is at 1138 Abbot Kinney Boulevard, (310)314-1555 or www.siperfumes.com.

Mr. Dillon said in a statement yesterday that the group set up a fake law firm that represented banks at real estate closings. When money for the real estate deals was wired to the firm's account, the defendants stole the money instead of issuing it for the sale, Mr. Dillon said. None of the eight are lawyers, he said. Mr. Dillon said checks to 30 home sellers eventually bounced because the funds were not available.

title: The Listings: Oct. 28 -- Nov. 3; DANIEL MacIVOR
description: The titles of Daniel MacIvor's plays generally fall into two categories: those that draw attention to themselves ("This Is a Play," "You Are Here") and those that draw attention to death and horror ("Here Lies Henry," "Never Swim Alone," "Monster"). So the fact that his beautifully performed drama at Urban Stages is called "Marion Bridge" should tip you off that it is a departure. Mr. MacIvor, a vastly underrated and prolific writer whose intimate plays often seem like Brechtian spins on Alfred Hitchcock, has written something more old-fashioned this time, a mostly naturalistic play about quiet lives in a small town in Nova Scotia. There's no murder, no shocks and no dark secrets waiting to be revealed. But in some ways, this moving drama, which tiptoes toward sentimentality without ever reaching it, is the most surprising play that he's ever written. When was the last time you saw a drama about three distinct, complex women that had nothing to do with their relationships with men? The MacKeigan sisters, whose affection for one another shows despite their constant bickering, are troubled, each in her own way. Agnes (Henny Russell) has a faltering acting career and an estranged daughter; Theresa (Christa Scott-Reed) is a rigid nun questioning her faith (a portrait on par with Cherry Jones's in "Doubt"); and childlike Louise (Susan Louise O'Connor, above right, with Ms. Scott-Reed) is married to her soap operas. They have all come home to see their dying mother, but while Mr. MacIvor often writes about death, this resolutely hopeful play is as much about making the most of life (despite all its flaws and disappointments). (Urban Stages, 259 West 30th Street, (212) 868-4444, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Manhattan; through Nov. 13.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUPT, ENID A.
description: HAUPT--Enid A. The Board, staff, and friends of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our fellow board member, friend, and esteemed benefactor, Enid A. Haupt, the greatest patron American horticulture has ever known. Her visionary and generous stewardship over many decades, as well as her impassioned enthusiasm for plants, particularly orchids, and fine horticulture have been instrumental in our modern history. In 1975, Mrs. Haupt came to the rescue of the Garden's historic Conservatory, the largest Victorian glasshouse in the nation. Her creative act saved this New York City Landmark from destruction. Upon completion of its rehabilitation in 1978, the Conservatory was named in her honor. In the mid-1990s, she was the leading private donor to the Conservatory's four-year, comprehensive restoration. She has been an enthusiastic proponent of the Conservatory's popular seasonal exhibitions and flower shows and a champion of the horticulture staff's fine work. A distinguished magazine publisher and editor, ardent and knowledgeable horticulturist, and award-winning gardener in her own right, Mrs. Haupt was honored by the Garden in 1973 for her contributions that reflected "her belief in the power of Nature to refresh and restore." She joined the Garden's Board of Managers in 1975, serving as Honorary Chairman of both the annual Conservatory Ball and the Conservatory Committee, and as a member of the Horticulture Committee. A generous philanthropist in many spheres, she was well known and respected for her support of many other gardens, green spaces, and horticultural organizations. Although Mrs. Haupt has left a legacy of beauty for millions to enjoy, we will miss her trusted advice, keen aesthetic judgment, elegance, enthusiasm, and true love for the Garden, the plants that live here, and the people who care for them. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Emeritus Mrs. Donald B. Straus, Vice Chairman Emerita Gregory Long, President Dr. Kim E. Tripp, Director of the Garden

title: 'Naruse: The Unknown Japanese Master'
description: MIKIO NARUSE (1905-1969) has been lauded as one of the neglected masters of Japanese cinema for so long and by so many estimable champions that his status as one of the medium's martyrs seems assured. Even so, the admiration of the likes of Susan Sontag has not done much for his profile in this country, and his work remains all but out of reach, which makes the Naruse retrospective at Film Forum all the more valuable. Naruse began working in the Japanese film industry at age 15 after his father died: "I had to immediately become an adult," he said. "It was the darkest period of my life." In time, he became celebrated for his melodramas and, in particular, for his sympathetic portrayal of geishas, widows and other hard-luck women. Set principally in postwar Tokyo, his bruising 1955 melodrama "Floating Clouds" concerns the relationship between a single woman (played by Hideko Takamine) and a married man (Masayuki Mori, above with Takamine), who became involved years before while working in Japanese-occupied Indochina. The elegance and indisputable hard punch of Naruse's storytelling become immediately clear the moment the lovers kiss and the director cuts, midclinch, to an almost identical shot of them kissing in the past, an edit that suggests this is a passion that transcends even time and space. Like many films in the series, "Floating Clouds" will be shown in a new 35-millimeter print. ("Naruse: The Japanese Unknown Master" continues through Nov. 17 at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Sixth Avenue, South Village, (212) 727-8110.)

Nicholas Minucci, 19, of Howard Beach, was charged with 19 offenses, including assault as a hate crime, robbery and weapons possession. If convicted, he could face 8 to 25 years in prison. The police said he was among a group of white men who chased three black men in the early morning of June 29. The three men ran, but one, Glenn Moore, was caught and severely beaten, the police said. Prosecutors charge that Mr. Minucci, making racial slurs, beat Mr. Moore and stole his sneakers. Mr. Moore's skull was fractured in the attack, they said. Mr. Minucci's lawyer, Michael Schwed, said yesterday that the three men had tried to rob Mr. Minucci, and that while Mr. Minucci was trying to hold Mr. Moore for the police, he fell to the ground and injured his head. Prosecutors noted yesterday that none of the three have been charged with any crime related to the incident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDMAN, ELEANORE S.
description: FREEDMAN--Eleanore S. On October 25, 2005. Beloved and devoted wife of Elliott for 65 years. Devoted mother of daughters Susan Prevo and Beryl Clymer; loving grandmother of Damion and Lindsey Prevo, Abbey and Benjamin Clymer; and loving mother-in-law of Bruce Prevo and William Clymer. Eleanore was predeceased by her sisters Mildred (Tashman) and Rita (Schockett). Eleanore Schwartz Freedman born in Brooklyn, NY on September 20, 1919 to Max and Pauline Schwartz, graduated from James Madison High School in Brooklyn, NY in 1936, where she met her future husband, Elliott. Eleanore attended Katherine Gibbs School and Saint John's University. She joined the Bright Chair Manufacturing Company until becoming personal secretary to the founding Professor and Executive Director of Food Research Lab in Long Island City, NY. On April 6, 1940 she married Elliott Freedman at the St. Moritz Hotel in NYC. During World War II, Eleanore was civilian secretary to the Signal Officer of the U.S. Army Signal Corps at the Laurenburg Maxton U.S. Army Air Force Base in North Carolina. After World War II, Eleanore, along with her husband, formed Butane Products-Flamex and became the Chief Financial Officer for the Corporation, which over the course of 25 years, became a major importing company. After selling the business to a subsidiary of Thomas Lee Associates, she and her husband retired in 1982, establishing residency at The Fountains Country Club, Lake Worth, Florida. Eleanore will be interred at the Freedman family plot at the New Montefiore Cemetery on Long Island when post hurricane conditions permit. Contributions may be made to local Heart or Kidney Funds and Foundations. May she rest in peace forever.

title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Pitches, Rivals Duck
description: Facing Fox's broadcast of Game 4 of the World Series, the other networks mostly ducked. Wednesday's prime-time schedule featured a number of reruns. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGICH, RONNIE
description: ROGICH--Ronnie, Chestnut55, died in New York City on October 24, 2005 of complications from viral pneumonia. She was born June 10, 1950 in Ione, Washington to Ranny and Ted Rogich. She was raised and spent the majority of her early life in Las Vegas where she attended Valley High School. After graduation, she began her professional dance career in The Folies Bergere Show. Ronnie went on to dance in a variety of other stage productions on the Strip and internationally with headliners Boyce and Hart, Sammy Davis, Jr. and others. Following her dance career, she worked with her brother, Sig Rogich, at R & R Advertising before moving to New York City in 1979. While in New York, Ronnie worked as a legal administrator for 25 years. She had a passion for her family and a love for collecting antiques. Ronnie was preceded in death by her mother, Ranny Rogich (born: Ragnheidur Arnadottir) and her brother, Steve Rogich. She is survived by her husband, Martin Chestnut of New York City and her son Ross Chestnut, currently attending Syracuse University; her father, Ted Rogich; her brother Ed Rogich and his wife Kathy; her brother Sig Rogich and his wife Lori, all of Las Vegas, NV; her brother and sister-in-law, Lt. Colonel Donald and Olivia Davis of Florida, currently stationed in Japan; her nieces and nephew, Britten Rogich of San Francisco, CA, Erin Rogich of Seattle, WA, Olivia Rogich and Sig Rogich, Jr., both of Las Vegas, NV. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM, Saturday, October 29, 2005 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made in Ronnie Rogich's name to the Nathan Adelson Hospice Foundation, 4141 Swenson Street, Las Vegas, NV 89119.
